Sign up *Invalid email address Got it Got it By Ammar Campa-Najjar November 19 However history looks back on this election, I like to believe that many of us will remember what comes next as not only a challenging time for diversity in America but also an empowering one. I understand why some people may struggle with the idea of this diversity. It’s still a radical idea after all, this notion of a nation with roots from every nation. Think about it, we are the only civilization on earth ever to be founded on this defiant worldview: that our individual differences don’t outweigh our common humanity. In many ways, America is still ahead of its time. I love this country because it’s a place where the ultimate comeback stories are written — including my family’s own story. Only in America can the son of a Hispanic woman from the barrio and an Arab man from an occupied territory have the freedom to reimagine his life and pursue his dreams. I spent my early years with my family under siege by American-made helicopters and F-16s that leveled entire buildings on the block where we lived. And then, just as surreally, I spent the second part of my life working for the U.S. government, entrusted with serving the American public. It’s not the perfect love story, but I know what I’ve witnessed in my life is nothing short of an American miracle. My father, Yasser Najjar, saw both his parents gunned down right in front of him when he was only 11 years old. Orphaned and outlawed, my father moved across Egypt, Lebanon and Morocco in search of a new home. On his 18th birthday, he found himself at a critical crossroads: continue seeking refuge across the Middle East, or move westward to America. He chose America, and America chose him. In 1986, on a sunny San Diego day, my father met my mother and they soon married. In 1993, my father asked the family to relocate to the Middle East for a few years so that he could help Yasser Arafat lead a secular unity government. Today, baba is a law-abiding, taxpaying, American Muslim who has devoted his life to promoting peace between Israel and the Palestinian people. His pain was turned into purpose, to make the world a better place for his children. Ammar Campa-Najjar as a young boy with his father, Yasser Najjar. (Courtesy of Ammar Campa-Najjar) My mother, Abigail Campa, the modest Mexican Catholic daughter of an orphaned migrant farmworker, showed me through a divorce and financial difficulty that you can dust yourself off and start again, that there’s dignity in a hard day’s work, and that your work doesn’t define you, it reveals you. She went from working as a receptionist to applying to work in a Walmart in her 50s to a career in real estate. She repeatedly inconvenienced her life for mine, whether it was choosing to live in a war zone just so her boys could have a father present or interrupting work to drive me home from school, to soccer games, to church. Her pain too was turned into purpose — to show her children all true love can do. I’ll never forget watching my mother weep when I was 9 years old. My abuelita flew from San Diego all the way to Tel Aviv to visit, only to be turned away. The second intifada — a brutal war between Israel and the Palestinian people — broke out the hour she landed. Nobody could enter, and nobody could leave. My mom’s source of comfort was so close, yet so far. I vowed to never show weakness or let her see me cry. So I didn’t cry when we said goodbye to our family in San Diego to live in the Palestinian territories for a few years. I didn’t cry when I watched a boy my age, Muhammad al-Durrah, get shot and killed while hiding behind a barrel. I didn’t cry the night they cut off the electricity to all of Gaza City, and I, my mom, stepmom, dad and younger brothers hid in the dark corner of a cold kitchen floor as they carpet bombed our neighborhood. I didn’t cry when we had to leave baba behind and finally return to the United States in August 2001. I didn’t cry when war clung to our lives like a disease and followed us to America. I didn’t cry that September when 19 terrorist hijackers committed mass murder at the World Trade Center. I didn’t cry that week when the Islamic school I attended was vandalized and declared unsafe to study or pray in. And then after working alongside hundreds of people who volunteered their labor and love to elect a man of color president of the United States, I left the only two people I’d never been separated from, my mom and younger brother, to pursue my dreams of working in Washington. Just before the inauguration in January 2013, I stood gawking at my new workplace — that grand, glorious, mysterious structure on 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, where Lincoln still walks at night. Ammar Campa-Najjar outside the White House. (Courtesy of Ammar Campa=Najjar) After not being considered Arab enough in Gaza, Latino enough for the barrio, or American enough in my own country, after so many shut doors, the door to all others finally opened. On that day, in those hallowed halls, I cried. The pain was given purpose: to live to tell you this story and to give others hope. The morning after the election, I went to work for President Obama in a building where President-elect Donald Trump’s transition team had already begun settling in. There was no time to process anything. I felt sad, scared, angry, confused and numb, all at the same time. I don’t know what’s going to happen next. All I can do is take things one day at a time and be ready to respond to what’s around the corner. We can take time to feel, but then we have to regroup and move forward as one nation. In 61 days, Obama will depart the White House and it will be up to all of us, ordinary citizens, to once again be the ones we’ve been waiting for. Let’s not seek comfort in the easy traps of either normalizing or demonizing the decision half of America has made. We must do what is hard, what is necessary and what is right. We must hold our families and communities close with a firm grip, but also extend an open hand to those who reject us. We must take a stand but also find a way to understand. America’s destiny has never been at the mercy of one person. It’s always been about all of us, placing our mortal hands on the arc of history and bending it slowly, sometimes too slowly, toward justice once again. So even in our darkest hours as a nation, don’t let anyone tell you our differences are too vast to bridge, or that your individual struggles are too hard to overcome. Chase the American Dream, have faith in the alchemy of America, turn your pain into purpose and begin writing your own ultimate comeback story. Ammar Campa-Najjar, the Hispanic-Arab American son of immigrants who was born in San Diego, works for the U.S. government in Washington. Read more Inspired Life: Deep in Trump country, this Clinton voter found renewed faith in her neighbors and America This election has divided the country. Getting Clinton and Trump voters talking is one way to heal. This professor devotes her life to countering dangerous speech. She can’t ignore Donald Trump’s. Latest Community Stories SEE MORE Whitby Chamber of Commerce accepting applications for role of CEO Mourning our pets: time moves on, but the memories don’t 5 tips when making the switch to winter tires Announcements Autos Real Estate Rentals YourClassifieds.ca Steelhead Trout Fillet discount: 45% | value: $55.00 | You Save: $25.00 Time Remaining: 0 Days Replacing a roof – an important home investment Local Ads In Your Neighbourhood Deals Coupons Flyers Business Listings Steelhead Trout Fillet discount: 45% | value: $55.00 | You Save: $25.00 Time Remaining: 0 Days Orthotics from Happy Feet Oshawa can ease back and leg pain Home News Business Search for new Port Perry water source continues... | Nov 19, 2016  |  Vote 0    0 Search for new Port Perry water source continues in Scugog Durham carrying out coring program in effort to find water Well water coring Jason Liebregts / Metroland PORT PERRY -- Geologists Steve Holysh and Beata Golas, from the York Peel Durham Toronto Ground Water Water Management Program, log core samples as Durham Region drilled down 230 feet to check the soil where it is planning to drill a test well at Scugog Line 3. Nov. 14, 2016 Well Water Coring Jason Liebregts / Metroland PORT PERRY -- Geologists Steve Holysh and Beata Golas, from the York Peel Durham Toronto Ground Water Water Management Program, log core samples as Durham Region drilled down 230 feet to check the soil where it is planning to drill a test well at Scugog Line 3. Nov. 14, 2016 Well Water Coring Jason Liebregts / Metroland PORT PERRY -- Geologist Steve Holysh from the York Peel Durham Toronto Ground Water Water Management Program explained the mapping process as Durham Region was in the process of drilling down 230 feet to check the soil where it is planning to drill a test well at Scugog Line 3. Nov. 14, 2016 Well water coring Jason Liebregts / Metroland PORT PERRY -- Mac Kouyoumjian took a core sample as Durham Region was in the process of drilling down 230 feet to check the soil where it is planning to drill a test well at Scugog Line 3. Nov. 14, 2016 next play/pause pre Port Perry Star By Chris Hall SCUGOG -- Durham’s efforts to address the quantity and quality of municipal water for Port Perry is continuing this fall. The Region began the process of searching for additional water supply and storage for the urban Port Perry area in early 2010 and has now identified a recommended solution. The preferred option is to drill additional wells and build a new treatment facility near the existing municipal wells just south of Port Perry and also establish a new elevated water storage tank near the Port Perry Walmart plaza. Durham’s goal, say Regional officials, is to find additional water to support future growth planned for Port Perry and address the unsavory characteristics that can now be found in the current municipal water supply. That effort took another step forward last week when crews began coring a hole near the existing Port Perry municipal wells to obtain soil samples that will help determine a water source and provide detailed information for when a well is eventually drilled. The coring continued this week as crews bore deeper into the ground, pulling up high-quality continuous soil samples in three-inch tubes that provided Durham officials with glimpses of what lay beneath the surface -- tell-tale signs of glacial movements from thousands of years ago and hints as to where the water is located. The plan, according to Regional officials, was to core down to a depth of about 70 metres or 230-feet. “This will tell us what the geotechnical formation is, where the water is,” explained Rich Tindall, a project manager with Durham Region. “This will help us figure out where the water is.” When the Region is confident that water can be found, it’s expected that a test well will be drilled in December and pump tests will be carried out in early 2017. The plan is to add another well to the three existing wells located on the east side of Simcoe Street, north of Scugog Line 3. A new treatment building is also planned for that location. Under the Durham Region Official Plan, the number of residents in the urban Port Perry area is expected to increase to just under 12,000 people by 2031, requiring the need for additional water. “Capacity is not an issue right now, but it will be down the road,” said Tindall. Regional officials also hope that any new water source will address the aesthetic qualities of the current municipal water that runs through Port Perry, specifically the ubiquitous “rotten egg” smell from hydrogen sulfide and high iron levels. “The driver right now is the aesthetics. The water quality is fine, it’s just the aesthetics,” added Tindall. “We hope we have a promising water supply of good quality and quantity.” Through its class environmental assessment, the Region tossed around a variety of options to address Port Perry’s need for additional potable water but ultimately decided on adding to the three existing wells that currently service Scugog’s largest urban area. Options that were cast aside included doing nothing, limiting growth in the urban areas and introducing water conservation measures. Durham also considered drilling wells at a new site, creating a new Lake Scugog-based water treatment plant and sourcing water from existing wells in Blackstock, Greenbank and Uxbridge, as well as those in Whitby or Oshawa. If everything goes as planned, Durham officials hope to design the treatment building in 2018 and start construction in 2020. The preliminary cost for the design portion is $3 million and construction will be approximately $14.8 million, said Tindall. Once additional water supplies are found, Durham must also find a way to store it. The current standpipe storage tank located near Port Perry High School currently does not have enough capacity to sufficiently meet fire needs or the forecasted Port Perry population, say Regional officials. During the current review, the Region considered five options for storage, including adding an elevated tank near the existing standpipe, introducing an elevated tank near the Scugog Line 4 and Old Simcoe Road intersection or somewhere along Hwy. 7A, and building an inground storage tank near the existing wells. Durham ultimately decided on an elevated tank east of Taylor Boulevard, within the Port Perry employment lands area. The existing standpipe storage tank will remain in service. Design work on the new storage tank is expected to take place in 2017 and construction is expected to begin in 2019 and take two years. The Region plans on holding another public meeting next spring in Port Perry to update residents on the search for a new water source. And, while Durham carries out its groundwater exploration program south of Port Perry, work continues just north of town to expand the Nonquon Water Pollution Control Plant. The Region needed to expand the sewage treatment plant as well to meet the needs of the growing urban Port Perry area. “It’s winding up, (construction) will be done somewhere near the end of the year,” said Tindall. The treatment building and accompanying tanks are “pretty much done” while construction work continues on the administration building, he added. It’s expected the work will be completed on budget and time, depending on weather. “We know it’s Canada,” said Tindall. Once construction is completed, it will take time for new facility to become operational. “The whole treatment plant, functioning and running by itself as intended, will be early 2017,” said Tindall. For more information about the work, visit www.durham.ca. Chris Hall is a reporter covering Scugog Township for Metroland Media Group’s Durham Region Division. He can be reached at CHall@durhamregion.com . Epaper search FOLLOW US: Home Archives Latest Arkansas Arkansas Politics 2016 Elections National National Politics World Legislature Weather Live Traffic Map Opinion/Voices Religion Today's Newspaper Right2Know Crime Weird News Interactives News Obituaries Arkansas Arkansas Stocks Markets Business Wire Technology Videos Today's Newspaper Jobs Business Weekend Movies Music Find a Restaurant Dining Today's Newspaper Events TV Listings Puzzles & Games Quizzes Entertainment Arkansas Razorbacks-WholeHogSports High School-Preps UA UALR ASU UCA Horse Racing Wally Hall- Like It Is Blog-Recruiting Guy College Football College Basketball Olympics NFL NFL Draft NBA MLB PGA NHL NASCAR TENNIS SOCCER Little Rock Marathon Today's Newspaper Sports Photo Galleries Staff Galleries & Multimedia AP Photos Top 10 Photos All Top Trending Videos News Recruiting Sports Features ActiveStyle HomeStyle Food Business More Videos Video Galleries Videos Travel High Profile Food Religion Special Sections Arkansas Bridal Community Wedding/Engagement Announcements Anniversary Announcements Family Style Dear Abby Blogs Columnists Polls Previous Features Tweets Big Bend Features Events Classifieds Jobs Homes Autos Crime Right2Know Traffic Broadway Bridge Archives News Tip Whole Hog Sports Arkansas Life Place an Ad Arkansas Daily Deal Sunday, November 20, 2016, 11:54 a.m. Home / Sports / Off the wire By Compiled from Democrat-Gazette press services This article was published November 19, 2016 at 2:20 a.m. Comments aAFont Size GOLF Hughes leads by 2 Mackenzie Hughes had another bogey-free round Friday and took care of the par 5s on the Plantation Course at Sea Island for a 5-under 67, giving him a two-shot lead over C.T. Pan going into the weekend of the RSM Classic at St. Simons Island, Ga., the final PGA Tour event of the year. Hughes at was at 14-under 128. There wasn't much of a gallery at Sea Island on another pristine day for scoring, so ideal that the cut came at 5-under par. That probably won't change for the weekend, especially with tournament host Davis Love III and Sea Island neighbors Zach Johnson and Matt Kuchar among those missing the cut. It was the lowest cut on the PGA Tour since 5 under at the 2015 Zurich Classic. Twenty-five players were separated by just five shots with two more rounds to play. That group includes Jim Furyk and Stewart Cink. Four shots behind was Jonathan Byrd, a five-time PGA Tour winner who spent last year on the Web.com Tour and still doesn't have full status. He is playing this week on a sponsor's exemption. Bryce Molder (Conway) shot a 5-under 65 and is 10 under going into the weekend. He is tied for 7th. Tag Ridings (Arkansas Razorbacks) had a 67 and is 7 under. Ken Duke (Arkadelphia, Henderson State) did not make the cut. Ko out front by 3 Lydia Ko shot a tournament-record 10-under 62 on Friday to take a three-stroke lead in the CME Group Tour Championship at Naples, Fla., putting the top-ranked New Zealander in position to sweep the season points title and player of the year award. The 2014 winner at Tiburon Golf Club, Ko birdied four of the first six holes and had seven birdies and a bogey on the back nine to get to 12-under 132 in the LPGA Tour season finale. Ryann O'Toole (67) and So Yeon Ryu (68) were tied for second, and Sei Young Kim (68) and Beatriz Recari (68) followed at 8 under. The 62 matched Ko's lowest score of the season, shot in the second round of her Wal-Mart NW Arkansas victory in June. First-round leader Shanshan Feng followed her opening 66 with a 73 to drop into a tie for 16th at 5 under. Stacy Lewis (Arkansas Razorbacks) shot a 2-under 70 and is 3 under after two rounds. Gaby Lopez (Razorbacks) had a 3-under 69 and is 3 over going into the weekend. Pair share 1-stroke lead Sergio Garcia and Francesco Molinari share a one-stroke lead halfway through the World Tour Championship in Dubai after shooting 5-under-par 67s on Friday. They each made six birdies and a solitary bogey, and moved to 9-under 135 totals, one better than overnight leader Lee Westwood. Westwood carded a 70, dropping a shot on the final hole after hitting his second shot into the water. Fellow Englishman Tyrrell Hatton (66), Austria's Bernd Wiesberger (67), South African Charl Schwartzel (67) and Dutchman Joost Luiten (69) were tied for fourth at 7 under in the season-ending championship of the European Tour. Defending champion Rory McIlroy improved on his horror start of 75 with a 68. BASEBALL Cashner to Rangers Right-hander Andrew Cashner is going home for a spot in the Texas Rangers' rotation. A person familiar with the decision told The Associated Press on Friday that the free agent pitcher and the team had reached an agreement on a $10 million, one-year deal. That person spoke on condition of anonymity because the deal was pending a physical and wasn't finalized, and the AL West champions had not made an official announcement. Cashner, 30, a Texas native who was a first-round draft pick out of TCU in 2008, finished last season with the Miami Marlins after the San Diego Padres traded him July 29. He was 5-11 with a 5.25 ERA in 28 games last season. Cashner has a 31-53 record with a 3.89 ERA in 202 career games. Are Marlins for sale? A Boston-based investment firm headed by former presidential candidate Mitt Romney and his oldest son, Tagg, looked into buying the Miami Marlins, South Florida's major league baseball franchise, in recent weeks, according to a report in the Boston Globe. A potential deal involving Boston-based Solamere Capital appears to have fallen through, according to the report. Jeffrey Loria has owned the Marlins since 2002. The Marlins declined to comment on the report. Matt Waldrip, who works in business development and external affairs at Solamere, told the Globe that Mitt Romney himself was not heavily involved in the talks. "Mitt Romney is associated with the firm but he's not leading the charge on this by any stretch of the imagination," Waldrip said. "We (had) been looking at the Marlins on behalf of some of the families that are a part of Solamere." TENNIS Murray advances Andy Murray retained his No. 1 ranking for at least another day. The Wimbledon champion qualified for the semifinals of the ATP finals on Friday in London by beating Stan Wawrinka 6-4, 6-2. Murray, who needs to do better than Novak Djokovic this weekend to finish the season as the top-ranked player, broke Wawrinka late in the first set and twice at the start of the second. Murray took over the No. 1 ranking at the Paris Masters this month, but Djokovic can take it back if the second-ranked Serb does better at the season-ending tournament. Djokovic has already qualified for the semifinals. Murray will next face Milos Raonic today, while Djokovic meets Kei Nishikori. In Friday's late match, Marin Cilic beat Nishikori 3-6, 6-2, 6-3 after the semifinal spots had already been decided. BASKETBALL Sterling drops lawsuit Former Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling has dropped a lawsuit that claimed the NBA, his wife and others conspired to illegally sell the team for $2 billion. Sterling's lawyer, Bobby Samini, said he filed a request Friday to have the federal appeals case dismissed and that a settlement was reached. He would not reveal details but said Sterling is "very happy with the outcome." However, the lawyer for his wife, Shelly Sterling, calls it a capitulation. Messages seeking NBA comment weren't immediately returned. Sterling was banned from the NBA for life in 2014 after it was revealed he'd made racist remarks to a friend. His antitrust suit was filed in 2014 after his wife agreed to sell the Clippers to ex-Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer. A judge dismissed the suit in March. SOCCER Soccer Federation, women’s team in contract talks Talks are ongoing between players for the World Cup-winning U.S. women’s national team and the U.S. Soccer Federation in advance of the Dec. 31 expiration of their current contract. The team played its final two matches of the season last week in California. On Sunday, the CBS news show 60 Minutes is set to air an interview with a group of players. The team has been playing under a memorandum of understanding between the U.S. Women’s National Soccer Team Players Association and the USSF that was struck in March 2013 and runs through the end of this year. Earlier this year, a group of players filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission alleging wage discrimination. They claimed that they are not paid the same as their counterparts on the men’s national team. Defender Becky Sauerbrunn told The Associated Press this week that the two sides met a couple of weeks ago and more talks are scheduled for this month and December. “We’re still fighting very hard for equal pay,” she said. “We’re not going to move on that. We’re always encouraged because we know that’s what we’re fighting for and we feel like we’re in the right to fight for something like that. Really, it’s convincing U.S. Soccer that we deserve that.” U.S. Soccer reiterated Friday that it is working to reach a new collective bargaining agreement with the women’s national team. Much of the disparity in wages between the men’s and women’s teams stem from the different ways the players are paid. The women earn salaries while the men are paid based on national team appearances, results and other factors. The pay structure was set up under separate collective bargaining agreements negotiated by unions for the men’s and women’s teams. There has been no decision in the EEOC complaint, which was brought by Sauerbrunn, Hope Solo, Alex Morgan, Megan Rapinoe and Carli Lloyd. All five were on the team that won the World Cup last year in Canada. The U.S. women’s team is coming off a disappointing showing at the Olympics this summer in Brazil, where they were ousted by Sweden in the quarterfinals. The U.S. had won three consecutive gold medals going into the Rio Games. SUBSCRIBE LOG IN LOG OUT REGISTER MY PROFILE Obituaries Events Jobs Real Estate Cars Classified PG Store November 20, 2016 12:54 PM 7-day Forecast Post-Gazette.com Archives Home News Local Sports Opinion A & E Life Business Video Photo Advertisement Canonsburg shooter cited combat trauma in mental health evaluation November 19, 2016 12:06 AM Darrell Sapp/Post-Gazette Investigation continues on Nov. 10 at the scene where two officers were ambushed as they responded to a domestic dispute. Michael Cwiklinski By Jonathan D. Silver / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette More than a week after authorities say Michael Cwiklinski gunned down his wife and two Canonsburg police officers before fatally shooting himself, investigators Friday still had not determined what spurred the former Army sharpshooter to deadly violence. But a glimpse into the 47-year-old machine shop technician’s frame of mind can be found in a four-page mental health evaluation that was part of a plea deal between his lawyer and the Washington County District Attorney’s office in a domestic violence case involving his wife. In the January evaluation, Mr. Cwiklinski, a self-described workaholic, disclosed that he had been in military combat and endured life-threatening experiences while in the Army. But besides a determination that “military combat was Mr. Cwiklinski’s trauma” and mentions of “periodic anger problems” and a separation from his wife, Dalia Sabae, nothing in the report indicated that he might be teetering on the edge of murder. Instead it stated that he had enjoyed a stable childhood and did not suffer from any depression, anxiety attacks, psychiatric problems or hospitalizations. The only medication he took was for blood pressure. “Suicidal ideas or intentions are denied,” Steven Adams, a licensed professional counselor, wrote in the report, which the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette went to court to obtain. “Homicidal ideas or intentions are denied.” Both determinations proved off the mark. On Nov. 10, Canonsburg police officers Scott Bashioum and James Saieva responded to a duplex on Woodcrest Drive for a domestic violence call. Investigators said Mr. Cwiklinski — who earned a sharpshooter marksmanship badge in the Army — shot and killed Officer Bashioum, 52, and wounded Officer Saieva. After a lengthy standoff, police found Mr. Cwiklinski dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound; they also found the body of Ms. Sabae, 28, and determined that he had killed her. At the time of her death, Ms. Sabae had a restraining order against her husband of less than two years. David Bayard Wolf, the attorney who represented Mr. Cwiklinski in the domestic violence case, said the Canonsburg native met his future wife, a native of Egypt, online and later in person while traveling in Russia. “Just as a disinterested observer, it was an odd coupling,” Mr. Wolf said this week. “She was a wonderful person. The whole situation is just very sad.” Six months after their wedding — presided over by District Judge Jay Weller, who would later oversee the plea deal in the couple’s domestic violence case — Ms. Sabae filed for a protection-from-abuse order, alleging that he struck her in the face with a bag full of cans at a Wal-Mart when she asked if she could help him, didn’t allow her to have friends, and “used sex as a way to threaten me about my green card.” Mr. Cwiklinski told his evaluator a different story, that he had “turned around with a bag in my hand, and I hit her, and she thought I was hitting her on purpose,” Mr. Adams said. “He was playing it as if it was a misunderstanding, and he seemed sincere. I didn’t know him well enough to know that he was sincere or not.” Earlier this year, prosecutors agreed to withdraw a simple assault charge and allow Mr. Cwiklinski to plead guilty to summary harassment. He had to attend 16 anger management sessions, which he completed, and undergo a mental health evaluation. Mr. Adams said he might have spent two sessions speaking with Mr. Cwiklinski before writing his report. He said he did nothing to verify any of the information Mr. Cwiklinski provided, assuming that if the court found any discrepancies he would be notified. “He just called up one day and said he needed an evaluation,” Mr. Adams recalled, adding that he never anticipated that Mr. Cwiklinski would end up as a killer. “I was surprised. I never would have seen that outcome coming,” Mr. Adams said. “I never would have expected the level of craziness.” Mr. Cwiklinski told Mr. Adams that he was the youngest of three children and came from an intact family. The counselor noted, “Childhood was emotionally and economically supportive and maritally intact.” Mr. Cwiklinski described himself as a community college dropout and self-taught machinist who worked at the same place for 28 years. Representatives for Tygard Machine & Manufacturing Co., where Mr. Cwiklinski was employed until recently, could not be reached for comment. His evaluation indicated that anger occasionally bubbled over, even in the workplace. “Mr. Cwiklinski has exhibited periodic anger problems. His anger manifests itself in aggressive but non-violent ways. He uses harsh and angry words. Angry verbal outbursts have been reported,” Mr. Adams wrote. “Loss of control of Mr. Cwilinski’s anger is an occasional occurrence. His anger passes quickly, in minutes. Marital difficulties have been caused by his anger. His anger has interfered with his occupational functioning on one occasion.” Mr. Adams’ report notes that Mr. Cwiklinski said he had been in combat, saw mutilated bodies and saw people “dying or being killed.” But there are no details about the combat experience. Records show that Mr. Cwiklinski was in the Army and the Army Reserve from December 1986 to October 1994, including during the Persian Gulf War. He was a heavy-wheel vehicle mechanic who received decorations consistent with having served during a period of combat while Operation Desert Storm was underway. But the only information in the public record shows only a 17-month deployment to South Korea just before his discharge. Mr. Cwiklinski joined the Army as specialist but left as a private, a lower grade. His evaluation indicates he received a general discharge, and information released by the Army related to his departure was redacted. Ms. Sabae indicated in her applications for restraining orders that she did not think her husband had weapons, although as far back as 1994 court records show he carried a Sig Sauer 9 mm pistol. Other than saying that Officer Saieva was shot with a rifle, police have not disclosed what type of gun was used last week, to whom it belonged, how Mr. Cwiklinski got it or whether he had it at the time his wife sought protection. Although cooperative, calm and friendly in person at his evaluation sessions, Mr. Cwilinski “had a way of explaining things away,” Mr. Adams said. “He came to a couple of sessions,” Mr. Adams said, “and when I started to push a little bit, he stopped coming.” Jonathan D. Silver: jsilver@post-gazette.com, 412-263-1962 or on Twitter @jsilverpg. Liz Navratil contributed. STAY CONNECTED   Events Calendar SHARE THIS PAGE Share Tweet +1 It Pin It Reblog   Email   Print FOLLOW US ON   FACEBOOK   TWITTER PINTEREST INSTAGRAM Tumblr Advertise with us Shoppers, stores prepare for Black Friday By Kathryn Cargo Nov. 18, 2016 at 10:21 p.m. Updated Nov. 19, 2016 at 6 a.m. • Academy Sports and Outdoors: 5 a.m. Friday • Bath and Body Works: 6 p.m. Thursday • Bealls: noon Thursday • Best Buy: 5 p.m. Thursday • Aeropostale: 6 p.m. Thursday • American Eagle: 6 p.m. Thursday • Bed, Bath and Beyond: 6 a.m. Friday • Big Lots: 6 a.m. Friday • Burkes Outlet: 7 a.m. Friday • Cavender's Boot City: 7 a.m. Friday • Buckle: 6 p.m. Thursday • Charlotte Russe: 10 a.m. Wednesday • Champs: 6 p.m Thursday • The Children's Place: 6 p.m. Thursday • The Children's Heaven: 6 p.m. Thursday • Claire's: 9 a.m. Wednesday • Dillard's: 8 a.m. Friday • Finish Line: 6 p.m. Thursday • Foot Locker: 6 p.m. Thursday • Francesca's: 8 a.m. Friday • GameStop: 5 a.m. Friday both locations • Gordon's Jewelers: 8 a.m. Friday • Harbor Freight: 8 a.m. Friday • H-E-B plus: 6 a.m. Friday • Hibbett Sporting Goods: 6 p.m. Thursday • Home Depot: 6 a.m. Friday • JCPenney: 3 p.m. Thursday • Justice: 8 p.m. Thursday • Kirkland's: 8 p.m. Thursday • Kohl's: 6 p.m. Thursday • Lowe's: 5 a.m. Friday • Maurices: 8 a.m. Friday • Melrose Family Fashions: 6 p.m. Thursday • Office Depot: 6 a.m Friday, both locations • Payless ShoeSource: 6 p.m. Thursday at Victoria Mall; 9:30 a.m. Friday on Rio Grande Street • PetSmart: 7 a.m. Friday • Perfumania: 6 p.m. Thursday • Pier 1 Imports: 8 a.m. Friday • RadioShack: 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. Friday • rue21, etc.: 6 p.m. Thursday • Sam's Club: 7 a.m. Friday • Sears: 6 p.m. Thursday • The Shoe Dept. Encore: 7 p.m. Thursday • Shop The World: 8 a.m. Friday • Spencer's: 6 p.m. Thursday • Target: 6 p.m. Thursday • Things Remembered: 8 a.m. Friday • Tractor Supply Company: 6 a.m. Friday • Trudy's Hallmark: 8 a.m. Friday • Victoria's Secret: 7 p.m. Thursday • Wal-Mart: 6 p.m. Thursday Safety tips • Park near a secondary entrance instead of near the store entrance. This will put the customer in a position to deal with less traffic, have better choice of spaces and lower risk of collision. • Customers should be aware of their surroundings while parking and look out for small cars, children and pedestrians. • Avoid parking parking between two cars, which can make it hard to see when backing out. • Vehicles should be parked in well lit areas, and drivers should have their keys ready when approaching their vehicle. • All purchases and valuables should be stored in the trunk. Source: AAA Texas Shopping tips Advertisers often use the terms such as "sales" and "lowest price." Sales should be a limited time and have a significant reduction in the retailer's price on an item. Lowest price fluctuates and is hard for customers to compare, so make sure the retailer has evidence their price is the lowest. Be aware and understand asterisks and fine print on advertisements. Customers should make sure to take advertisements with them about the items they want to buy. Planning a budget helps customers track what they need and how much they want to spend. Be aware of the return policy for items purchased. Customers should also be cautious of the store credit card offers, which can often have high interest rates or expensive annual fees. Source: Better Business Bureau Black Friday is more than just a shopping spree for Krystal Hancock and her family. It's a long-standing family tradition. Hancock, along with her immediate and extended family, have been taking on Black Friday adventures for more than 20 years, she said. About 20 to 25 of four generations of women in the family, including Hancock's children and her grandmother, wear matching T-shirts as they search for all their Christmas gifts. The women gather after their Thanksgiving meals and make a game plan based on what they want, the advertisements for products and what times stores open, Hancock said. Black Friday gives her a chance to spend time with extended family she doesn't see often, she said. "When I moved out of state, that's something I could look forward to - Black Friday shopping," the 31-year-old Victoria native said. "As a big family, you have different Thanksgivings you have to go to. When we get together for Black Friday shopping, it is everyone. It consists of laughing, joking and telling stories. If you hadn't seen someone for a year or two, it is a way of catching up." To succeed during Black Friday shopping, research is essential, said Mary Hancock, Krystal Hancock's mother. While shopping, the family will have relatives stand in line with carts while others go out and find sale items, Mary Hancock said. Matching T-shirts makes the process easier, she said. "We're able to find our family members really fast," she said. "If we're looking for the basket with the teenagers, we're able to spot them in a crowd." Mary Hancock doesn't know yet what items she will hunt down, but she landed great deals last year, she said. She bought $100 worth of items from JCPenney for almost nothing with a $100 discount coupon. "Be patient and don't forget to have fun," she said. Because stores have started opening on Thanksgiving Day for Black Friday sales, the family heads out to Wal-Mart first on Thursday and then hits the mall. After shopping at the mall, some family members go home to sleep while others shop through the night, Krystal Hancock said. Wal-Mart opens at 6 p.m. Thursday as well as many stores in the Victoria Mall. Managers at Kohl's in Victoria are preparing for Black Friday sales by making sure the store is overstaffed for Thanksgiving and Black Friday and organizing extra merchandise, said Troyleen Roberson, Koh's administrator. On a regular day, Koh's will staff about 70 employees, but on Thanksgiving and Black Friday about 130 employees will work. Black Friday shopping benefits customers because they are often able to purchase items for less than 50 percent of the original cost, Roberson said. Kohl's opens 6 p.m. Thursday for the third year in a row. Previously the store would open early in the morning on Black Friday. The extended hours into Thanksgiving help employees manage the large sale crowds and makes it easier on customers, she said. "Before, we basically had to have security because managing the crowds were so bad," she said. "Now, we still have lines but it gives a bigger window of opportunity to shop, and it's not all at once." During the 10 years Roberson has worked at Kohl's, she noticed that many families make Black Friday shopping an extension of their Thanksgiving holiday. "We have a lot of ladies that come in all times of the night in teams, and they just love shopping together," Roberson said. "It seems like a great experience." The most popular items at Kohl's during Black Friday sales are small electric appliances and gaming systems, Roberson said. Many people will buy online for Black Friday sales and pick up their items at their chosen Koohkl's location, Roberson said. Customers can start buying items online Monday and pick them up when the store opens for sales. Jade and Madalynn Bridal Boutique will have a Black Friday sale for the first time since it has been open for nine years, said manager Erika Olguin. From 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Friday all gowns in the store will be 40 percent off, and Black Friday hours will be 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. "It'll be fun to have one; it will be a new experience," she said. "Everyone is going to be shopping and looking for deals, so this will help get the name out more." Watchlist X × × × Mad Money with Jim Cramer Mad Money Video Full Shows Jim Cramer About Mad Money Disclaimer Cramer breaks down the retailers for Black Friday — one winner proves the mall isn’t dead Abigail Stevenson | @A_StevensonCNBC Friday, 18 Nov 2016 | 6:52 PM ETCNBC.com SHARES show chapters <p>Cramer breaks down the retailers for Black Friday: One winner that proves the mall isn&rsquo;t dead</p> <p>Jim Cramer goes down his playbook of retailers hanging on by a thread, and discovered one winner of the mall.</p> Cramer breaks down the retailers for Black Friday: One winner that proves the mall isn’t dead    Friday, 18 Nov 2016 | 6:25 PM ET | 08:34 Retail has been all over the map lately, and Jim Cramer found it almost unbelievable. "We have too many retailers. Some are hanging on by a thread. Some simply aren't needed. Some seem atavistic and antediluvian and they are just waiting to be destroyed by Amazon. Then we have other retailers that could be saved by the, well, Trump," the "Mad Money" host said. With the drastic difference in retail options ahead of Black Friday, Cramer reviewed the trends and how the market has reacted to them. Shares of Macy's, Kohl's and Nordstrom have all done well since the election. Cramer speculated this is due to anticipated tax cuts that the Republicans will create, which will mean more cash for shoppers. Oli Scarff | Getty Images Cramer was also impressed by J.C. Penney, whose stock rose despite the fact that it reported mediocre numbers and slashed guidance. This was a reflection of the optimism in the stock market. Home Depot pulled ahead of Lowe's, and Cramer was "aghast" at how much stronger Home Depot has performed on all levels, especially the big ticket appliances. He believes Home Depot has a better idea of what customers want right now. Cramer picked Target over Wal-Mart, as well. Target put up stellar numbers and indicated a robust back-to-school and upcoming holiday season. Next week, Dollar Tree will report and Cramer will compare the numbers versus Wal-Mart, TJX and Ross Stores, where he thinks the growth was tremendous. Ross Stores confirmed Cramer's thesis that discount stores would have full priced merchandise because of the disarray from broad line retailers like Macy's. Sporting goods were a mixed bag, as Foot Locker seemed to benefit from the sneaker war going on. Dick's Sporting Goods also reported good numbers, thanks to Sports Authority closing. One pleasant surprise for Cramer was Best Buy, which was supposed to be hurt by Amazon by now. "This stock is back to its just won't quit days, although it did have a refreshing pullback today," Cramer said. The retailers in the mall were truly sad, with only one shining star. The biggest losers were Gap Stores and Abercrombie. Williams Sonoma saw a surprising 4.5 percent decline at its Pottery Barn brand. The one place that could have a comeback in sight is L Brands, as Amazon couldn't replicate Bath & Body Works and Pink has been strong. The problem was Victoria's Secret, Cramer said. He thinks management is addressing the issues. The new winner of the mall was Children's Place, which reported an amazing quarter. The stock rallied in response. "Children's Place … has cracked the code and is winning both online and off. It's pure execution: the right styles and the right sizes. The Childrens Place is the NVIDIA of retail and a reminder that not only is the mall not dead, but you can make a ton of money in it if you have the right stuff," Cramer said. Questions for Cramer? Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBC Want to take a deep dive into Cramer's world? Hit him up! Mad Money Twitter - Jim Cramer Twitter - Facebook - Instagram - Vine Questions, comments, suggestions for the "Mad Money" website? madcap@cnbc.com Abigail StevensonDigital Producer Related Securities Symbol Price   Change %Change AMZN --- PLCE --- TJX --- LB --- BBY --- SHOW COMMENTS Please add a username to view or add comments Public Username for Commenting JOIN THE DISCUSSION To learn more about how we use your information, please read our Privacy Policy and Terms of Service. Cramer's New Book
Home Mail Flickr Tumblr News Sports Finance Celebrity Answers Groups Mobile More Yahoo Search Search 0 Mail Tech Home Follow Us Reviews How To Deals Video Games Pogue Apple Apple’s iPhone call logging is a feature, not a security scare Chris Smith BGR NewsNovember 19, 2016 Reblog Share Tweet Pin it Share A Russian company that makes iPhone-hacking software said earlier this week that Apple quietly collects iPhone call data in iCloud, including both cellular voice calls and FaceTime calls. But it turns out that’s a feature built into iOS and macOS for the user’s “convenience.” So there’s no point freaking out about it. That said, Apple could certainly have done a better job informing the user what happens with call data. DON’T MISS: All the best pre-Black Friday deals you can buy right now at Walmart, Best Buy and Amazon If you’ve got iCloud enabled on your Apple devices, and most people do, then Apple will record data from all your calls, whether it’s a regular phone call or VoIP-based calls including FaceTime, Skype, WhatsApp, Viber and others. Everything gets synced to the cloud, complete with phone numbers, call dates and times, and call duration. The reasoning here is pretty simple. Apple wants you to be able to access those calls and return missed calls from any of your devices. This is possible through Apple’s Continuity feature. The actual contents of a call aren’t saved in iCloud. After all, Apple doesn’t listen in on your conversations. However, the worry with some people is that the data stored in iCloud can be decrypted by Apple, and can be shared with law enforcement if a warrant requires Apple to do so. Hackers might also access call history, and Elcomsoft updated its Phone Breaker software to extract call records from iCloud using only an authentication token for an account from a computer belonging to the account holder. To make those call records disappear, you have to delete them from a device. Otherwise, they’ll remain in iCloud for up to four months. FaceTime call invitations can be stored for up to 30 days. “We offer call history syncing as a convenience to our customers so that they can return calls from any of their devices,” an Apple spokesperson said about the matter. “Device data is encrypted with a user’s passcode, and access to iCloud data including backups requires the user’s Apple ID and password. Apple recommends all customers select strong passwords and use two-factor authentication.” MacRumors notes that while Apple may not explain exactly what happens in the background, it does state that it collects call history for iCloud backups in a 63-page white paper about iOS security. Trending right now: Today’s your last chance to get a NES Classic 9 paid iPhone apps on sale for free for a limited time Best Buy is offering a solid Black Friday deal on the new Google Home See the original version of this article on BGR.com Reblog Share Tweet Pin it Share What to Read Next Ivanka isn’t the only reason these photos of Trump meeting Abe are problematic Quartz People are wildly misinterpreting a “heartwarming” video of a polar bear playing with a dog Quartz iOS 10 Hidden Feature: The Magnifier Yahoo Tech Apple Reportedly Throttling Verizon iPhone 7 (Update: Confirmed) Tech Media Network (Tom's Guide) New hybrid console takes Nintendo on the go Yahoo Tech The Truth Behind the Google Pixel Account Ban Tech Media Network (Tom's Guide) Privacy |Terms |About our Ads |Suggestions Brought to you by Yahoo News Network

Port St. Lucie father wants justice for son fatally shot by police Laurie K. Blandford and Nicholas Samuel , Treasure Coast 10:48 p.m. EST November 18, 2016 FacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedIn Fatal police-involved shooting in Port St. Lucie  Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! Family members console each other near the scene where 25-year-old Samson Fleurant, accused of approaching police with a machete, was fatally shot at his residence by a Port St. Lucie police officer Friday, Nov. 18, 2016, after a domestic disturbance call to the home on the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue in Port St. Lucie.  XAVIER MASCAREÑAS/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS Fullscreen Port St. Lucie Police Chief John Bolduc (center) speaks to news media about the fatal police-involved shooting Friday, Nov. 18, 2016, at a home on the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue in Port St. Lucie. Bolduc said the incident is being investigated by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement.  XAVIER MASCAREÑAS/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS Fullscreen Ylovy Fleurant, father of Samson Fleurant, talks to news media about his son Friday, Nov. 18, 2016. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 17 2 of 17 3 of 17 4 of 17 5 of 17 6 of 17 7 of 17 8 of 17 9 of 17 10 of 17 11 of 17 12 of 17 13 of 17 14 of 17 15 of 17 16 of 17 17 of 17 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show CaptionsLast SlideNext Slide Ylovy Fleurant, father of Samson Fleurant, talks to news media about his son Friday, Nov. 18, 2016. Samson Fleurant was fatally shot as Port St. Lucie police were responding to domestic disturbance call on the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue in Port St. Lucie. (Photo: XAVIER MASCAREÑAS/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS) 757 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDIN 13 COMMENTEMAILMORE PORT ST. LUCIE — When Ylovy Fleurant moved his family to the U.S., he said, he wanted to get them away from killings in Haiti. “I came here for a better life,” Ylovy Fleurant said. “I didn’t bring my son here to get killed.” Ylovy Fleurant said he was in shock Friday night as he stood beyond the yellow crime scene tape surrounding his Port St. Lucie home after his 25-year-old son, Samson Fleurant, was fatally shot that afternoon by a police officer. While Ylovy Fleurant was at work, a family member at his home in the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue called 911 about 2:15 p.m. to report a person, later identified as his son, was cutting up the house with a knife, Police Chief John Bolduc said. Officers arrived and found Samson Fleurant armed with a machete, Bolduc said. He then charged at the officers. Officer Kenneth Frid tried to stop Samson Fleurant with a Taser, Bolduc said, but it didn’t work. When Samson Fleurant continued with the machete toward them, Bolduc said, K-9 Officer Colin Duncombe shot him. Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share Port St. Lucie Police Chief John Bolduc talks about the officer-involved shooting in Port St. Lucie on Friday. NICHOLAS SAMUEL/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS Josue Maury, who lives nearby, said he drove by the house and saw officers around a man who appeared to be unarmed lying motionless on the grass in front of the home. Maury said officers told him to keep driving. Samson Fleurant was taken to Lawnwood Regional Medical Center & Heart Institute in Fort Pierce, where he died. It's unknown how many times Samson Fleurant was shot or whether drugs were a factor in the incident, Bolduc said. Florida Department of Law Enforcement officials were taking over the investigation, which is typical for officer-involved shootings. Ylovy Fleurant said what officials have told him of the incident doesn’t sound like his son. He said he had a nice son who never gave him trouble in 25 years. “My son is not a bad guy,” Ylovy Fleurant said. “He’s a cool guy.” When Samson Fleurant wasn’t working 12- to 13-hour shifts at Wal-Mart to pay for college or going to church on Sundays, he would watch TV at home, said his father. Family members console each other near the scene where 25-year-old Samson Fleurant, accused of approaching police with a machete, was fatally shot at his residence by a Port St. Lucie police officer Friday, Nov. 18, 2016, after a domestic disturbance call to the home on the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue in Port St. Lucie.  (Photo: XAVIER MASCAREÑAS/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS) Ylovy Fleurant said he didn’t know what happened inside his home Friday afternoon because he was working at the time. He came home after work to find police officers had blocked off a large area surrounding his home and learned somebody had been shot. He said he became emotional when he found out it was his son. He said his wife wasn’t home either because she also was at work. When she got to the house and learned about her son, she sobbed in front of their home. It’s unknown who inside the house called 911, but Ylovy Fleurant said his three daughters were home with his son at the time of the disturbance. He said the 3- to 4-foot machete was used only to cut meat and never as a weapon. Samson Fleurant had no criminal history in Florida, according to the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. A check of court records in Martin, St. Lucie and Indian River counties also show he has no traffic infractions or civil actions filed against him. Ylovy Fleurant said he’s lived in the area for 25 years — two years in the Port St. Lucie home and Fort Pierce before that. He said he’s a pastor at the Fort Pierce Wesleyan Church. Even though he became a U.S. citizen in 2006, he said, he regrets that now. Ylovy Fleurant said he doesn’t understand how someone without a gun could be shot, and he doesn’t think the shooting was justified. Not only are law enforcement officials biased against black people, he said, they need more training. Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share A witness talks about the officer-involved shooting in the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue in Port St. Lucie on Friday, Nov. 18, 2016. NICHOLAS SAMUEL/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS Duncombe, who shot Samson Fleurant, is a 47-year-old black officer who has been with the Police Department for 18 years, said police spokesman Master Sgt. Frank Sabol. Frid, who used the Taser, is a 47-year-old white officer with 11 years of service. Sgt. Tara Pavlyshin, a 44-year-old white officer with 15 years of service, was the supervisor on scene, Sabol said. Lt. Leo Niemczyk, a 47-year-old white officer with 14 years of service, was the district commander on scene. All four officers had been placed on paid administrative leave while the investigation is ongoing, Bolduc said. If the officers were lying about what Samson Fleurant son did, said his father, God will judge them in the end. “God is a powerful God; he will deal with it,” Ylovy Fleurant said. “My son will have justice.” Reporter Melissa E. Holsman contributed to this report. Port St. Lucie Police Chief John Bolduc (center) speaks to news media about the fatal police-involved shooting Friday, Nov. 18, 2016, at a home on the 600 block of Southwest Colleen Avenue in Port St. Lucie. Bolduc said the incident is being investigated by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement.  (Photo: XAVIER MASCAREÑAS/TREASURE COAST NEWSPAPERS) TCPALM Man dies after police-involved shooting in Port St. Lucie 757 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDIN 13 COMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://www.tcpalm.com/story/news/local/st-lucie-county/2016/11/18/port-st-lucie-father-wants-justice-son-fatally-shot-police/94102616/ More Stories Fatal police-involved shooting in Port St. Lucie Nov. 18, 2016, 10:20 p.m. Red, White and Blue Concert at St. Lucie West Centennial High School Nov. 18, 2016, 9:03 p.m. Man dies after police-involved shooting in Port St. Lucie | Video Nov. 18, 2016, 8:08 p.m. Shrinking Shores: How Florida leaders are failing the state’s famous beaches Nov. 18, 2016, 12:32 p.m.
Home Mail Flickr Tumblr News Sports Finance Celebrity Answers Groups Mobile More Yahoo Search Search 0 Mail Tech Home Follow Us Reviews How To Deals Video Games Pogue Apple Daryl may have quietly made ‘The Walking Dead’ great again Chris Smith BGR NewsNovember 19, 2016 Reblog Share Tweet Pin it Share Following last week’s The Walking Dead, I was surprised, again, at how silly stupid Rick and Co. can be sometimes. The Alexandria gang seemed utterly unprepared to deal with Negan’s arrival, even though they all knew he was coming to collect his protection tax. That said, there was a moment in the episode almost everyone missed that might make Daryl great again. And with him, the entire season. Beware, spoilers follow below. DON’T MISS: All the best pre-Black Friday deals you can buy right now at Walmart, Best Buy and Amazon There’s one scene in episode four where Daryl blinks strangely, and the camera focuses on him. The easiest interpretation for his blinking (see GIF below) is that he’s readjusting to the sunlight, considering that he spends most of the time in darkness. daryl-morse-codeMore But, as Business Insider explains, Daryl might be communicating in Morse code with Rick. He might be telling him either “I East,” or “HT” for Hilltop. Aside from that blinking sequence, Daryl chooses not to speak, or he’s not allowed to. Negan explicitly forbids Rick from talking to Daryl. But a tracker and hunter like Daryl might be able to find a way to communicate without Negan realizing. That “I East” indication would be enough for Rick & Co to know where to look for Negan’s base, since the location of the Saviors’ hometown isn’t known yet. The fact that Daryl would want to communicate with Rick in such a manner could show that he has not been broken. He may be riddled with guilt after causing Glenn’s death, not to mention he now believes that Maggie may have died as well. But he did not give in. We also know he’s not willing to say his name is Negan now, as he refuses to take Dwight up on his offer at the end of the episode — just a word (Negan) is needed for Daryl to get his bike back. A Daryl who wants to fight back and who wants to keep in contact with Rick is a dangerous Daryl. At least for Negan and his men. Is this all wishful thinking? It might very well be. But then why is there a scene in the same episode that shows a Morse code alphabet hanging on a wall in Rick and Michonne’s home? Surely, Rick and the gang may have figured out that such a means of communication might come in handy in dangerous situations such as the Negan crisis. We’ll have to wait for the next episodes of The Walking Dead to see whether Daryl was indeed talking to Rick. TechnoBuffalo Site Navigation Content All News Reviews Videos Galleries Products Giveaways Sections Menu Left Mobile Tablets Gaming Apps Accessories Computers Gadgets Internet Menu Right Business Cameras Cars Design Home & TV Lifestyle Software Science Series Ask The Buffalo Buffalo Gear Guess the Phone Rettinger’s Riffs Rumor Roundup The TechnoBuffalo Show TechnoBuffalo Plays More The Crew About Us News Tips In the News Work at TechnoBuffalo Advertise With Us Facebook Google+ Instagram Pinterest RSS Tumblr Twitter YouTube Scrolling Enable Endless Scrolling Disable Endless Scrolling Share Tweet +1 Submit Front Page /Streaming Media/Deals/Gallery Streaming Media Roku’s Black Friday deals revealed By Todd Haselton | November 18, 2016 Share If you don’t own a Roku, there’s no better time to get in on the streaming product everyone loves. Roku recently sent us an email with all of its Black Friday deals ahead of time, and where you’ll be able to find each product. There may be more from additional retailers in the future, so we’ll let you know if those pop up, but here’s a taste of what to expect. Beginning on November 20, Best Buy will sell the Roku Streaming Stick for $35.99, down from the standard price of $49.99.  Best Buy will also sell the Roku 3 for $49.99, down from $99.99. Beginning on November 24, Walmart will sell the Roku Express+ for $25, down from the standard price of $39.99. This is probably the best option for folks who want to try Roku but aren’t yet sure if they want to cut the cord, since it’s the most affordable option. On November 21, Kohl’s will sell the Roku 2 for $44.99, down from the standard $59.99 price the retailer usually sells it for. Some of these aren’t the newest Roku players Keep in mind that Roku recently refreshed its portfolio with new 4K-ready products. The Roku Express+ is the newest and cheapest out of all of the products on sale for Black Friday, but the discounts on products like the Roku 3, a great product, are worth the fact that you’re buying a generation-old product. If you want the newest, look for the company’s new Premiere-branded products. Topics #Roku #Black Friday 2016 #Roku Todd Haselton Todd Haselton has been writing professionally since 2006 during his undergraduate days at Lehigh University. Shopping 6 0 0 November 18, 2016 Black Friday 2016 Deals And Ads: Sam’s Club’s Samsung Pre-Black Friday Nov. 19 Sale Starts Tonight — How Does It Compare To Walmart And Amazon Sales? Phillip Dengler Black Friday 2016 is exactly a week away from today, and numerous national retailers are holding early pre-Black Friday sales. Amazon and Walmart are probably the two most popular stores who are treating their customers to early savings, but Sam’s Club has also been one of the more active retailers. Last week, they held their annual one-day sale on November 12, which featured Black Friday prices on a variety of electronics and home items. While Sam’s Club’s official general pre-Black Friday event does not begin until Sunday, they are actually kicking things off early with a selection of electronics deals from premium manufacturer Samsung. The sale begins online at 12:01 a.m. tonight, and traditional brick-and-mortar locations will open at 7 a.m. A full listing of the sale items can be found at BestBlackFriday.com, but here are the top deals from the ad. Disclaimer: The author, Phillip Dengler, is the owner of BestBlackFriday.com, which is referenced in this article. The Inquisitr holds no ownership. [Image by Sam’s Club] As the screenshot shows, this sale is entirely made up of Samsung items. While a single-item sale is usually not newsworthy, Samsung is probably the most common brand for electronics deals on Black Friday. Select items actually offer better discounts than Black Friday, so it could make sense to purchase them a week earlier in order to avoid the rush. Par for the course with Sam’s Club, limited quantities are available on every item, and there are no rain checks. 10.1″ Samsung Galaxy Tab A w/Free 32GB MicroSD Card for $188.84 (reg. $288.84) 8″ Samsung Galaxy Tab A w/Free Pouch for $118.24 (reg. $188.88) Samsung 2.1 Soundbar with Wireless Subwoofer for $139.88 (reg. $199.88) Samsung 24″ Class 720p TV form $98.88 (reg. $138.88) Samsung 27″ Curved 1080p Monitor for $169 (reg $249) Samsung 40″ Class 1080p Smart TV for $238 (reg. $328) Samsung 4k Blu-ray Disc Player for $189.88 Samsung 55″ Class 4K SUHD HDR Smart TV for $978 (reg. $1,378) Samsung 55″ Class 4K UDH Curved Smart TV + Samsung 2.1 Curved Soundbar w/Wireless Subwoofer for $698 (reg. $1,099) Samsung 70″ Class 4K UHD Smart TV + $150 Gift Card for $1,248 Samsung 8-Channel 1080p HD Security System with 1TB Hard Drive for $199 (reg. $299) Samsung Blu-ray Disc Player for $44.88 (reg. $64.88) Samsung Level U Pro Wireless Headphones for $39.88 (reg. $99.99) Samsung Radiant Connect Speaker for $79.88 (reg. $129.88) Forget Black Friday, Sam’s Club has a serious one-day sales event this Saturday https://t.co/mTy28wXNCU — David Papp (@DavidPapp) November 16, 2016 Shipping Options Unlike other retailers, Sam’s Club does not have a general rule for shipping. Certain expensive items may incur shipping charges, while select cheap items may ship for free. The good news is that the majority of the items in this sale will ship for free. As a general rule, paying shipping charges on any Black Friday, Cyber Monday, or Thanksgiving sale is unnecessary. Many retailers, including Best Buy and Target, are offering free shipping on every order with no minimum this holiday season. Seeing as most Samsung deals are going to be over $50, the majority will qualify for free shipping. If you come across one that does not, you should look elsewhere because shipping charges can drastically reduce an otherwise great deal. Comparisons to Black Friday Unlike in this sale, Sam’s Club is not offering many Samsung televisions on Black Friday. The closest comparison for televisions is the Samsung 75″ 4K UHD Smart TV (UN75JU641DFXZA) for $1,998 on Black Friday. Tonight’s sale has a Samsung 70″ Class 4K UHD Smart TV + $150 gift card for $1,248. While these are not the same television, they are still fairly comparable. By shopping tonight’s sale, you can pay more than $700 less, and you will also receive a Sam’s Club gift card valued at $150. Tonight’s sale also features the 10.1″ Samsung Galaxy Tab A with a free 32GB MicroSD Card for $188.84, which is a savings of $100. On Black Friday, Sam’s Club will have the same exact deal, so this is an opportunity to get it early. Comparisons to Walmart and Amazon Pre-Black Friday Sales As Amazon announced in a press release earlier this week, they started their “Black Friday Deals Week” sale earlier today. Many of the Samsung televisions are still a few days away, but Amazon claims the “lowest prices on select Samsung TVs.” One deal that is live now is the Samsung UN65KS8500 Curved 65-Inch 4K Ultra HD Smart LED TV for $1,597.99, which is a discount of $400. The closest comparable deal is the one mentioned above — the Samsung 70″ Class 4K UHD Smart TV + $150 gift card for $1,248. While there are differences among both televisions, you can get a set that is five inches larger for more than $300 less. For the average viewer, the difference in quality should be fairly negligible. Walmart’s pre-Black Friday sale is loaded with Samsung televisions. They are offering the Samsung 40″ 6200 Series Full HD Smart LED TV for $227, which is a discount of $522.99. Sam’s Club’s sale is featuring a Samsung 40″ Class 1080p Smart TV for $238, which is a discount of $90. In this instance, you can get a more expensive Samsung TV at Walmart and pay $11 less. Regardless, this sale still has prices that are very comparable to what you will see on Black Friday. The popular opinion is that Black Friday and Cyber Monday are the best days of the year to get a deal, but careful planning can net you prices just as good by shopping a few days earlier. [Featured Image by Scott Olson/Getty Images] Now Read This: Black Friday 2016 Ads: Where To Find The Best Video Game And Electronics Deals From Target, Walmart, Best Buy, And More Share 6 Tweet 0 Share 0 Share 0 Pin It 0 Author Phillip Dengler Tags: black friday 2016, sam's club Comments LATEST HEADLINES How Congress Can Change Final 2016 Electoral College Map, If Faithless Electors Don’t Stop Trump WWE News: Could Shinsuke Nakamura Be Heading To The Main Roster Following NXT Takeover: Toronto Loss? Updated: November 20, 2016 @ 11:54 am Full Forecast Weather sponsored by Blaze Air Search Toggle navigation Subscriptions Subscribe Manage Subscription Vacation Stop Go to e-Edition Change Password Report An Issue FAQ News Local Business Elections Ask Sam Scott Sexton State / Region Nation / World E-Edition Blogs Lottery Results Submit A News Tip Search Journalnow.com Crime Obituaries Sports High School / Prep Zone Auto Racing College Wake Forest Blog: My Take On Wake Winston-Salem State Blog: Ram Ramblings Appalachian State Blog: App Trail Outdoors Carolina Panthers Dash baseball Pro Sports Golf Columnists Calendar Blogs Entertainment Relish Events Contests Music Dining & Drinks The Arts The Sandbox Tim Clodfelter Calendar Purchase Event Tickets Opinion Columnists Editorials Letters to the Editor Submit a Letter to the Editor Join our Panel Living Food Food: Michael Hastings Recipe Search Home & Garden Gardening: Amy Dixon The Coupon Corner Blog: Dishing It Out Blog: Veggin Out Advice Blogs Winston-Salem Monthly Spark Magazine Carolina Weddings Community Community Milestones Submit community milestone Scene and Heard Celebrations Submit a Celebration Religion Calendar Submit to religion calendar Calendar Photo Galleries Request Photos Reader Photos Submit Photos Video Journal West Nonprofit Notebook:Guardian ad Litem volunteers needed HM10003015705 HM10003015705 12 hrs ago (…) Guardian ad Litem volunteers needed The Forsyth County Guardian ad Litem program is accepting applications from people who would like to serve as volunteer advocates for children in foster care. Training is provided, with the classes beginning Jan. 21. To learn more or to apply, go to www.volunteerforgal. org or call (336) 779-6650. Newcomers group to meet Tuesday The Newcomers and Neighbors of Winston-Salem will meet at 9:45 a.m. Tuesday at Trinity Presbyterian Church, 1416 Bolton St. For more information, email wsnandn@aol.com or go to www.wsnewcomers. blogspot.com. Angel Tree program looking for sponsors The Salvation Army of Greater Winston-Salem needs “corporate angels” to take part in its annual Angel Tree program. Companies can decorate a tree, box or barrel and collect toys at their locations, or email the Salvation Army to say how many Angels they want to adopt. More than 7,000 local children ages 12 and younger receive Christmas gifts from the Angel Tree. The children are members of families that apply for Christmas assistance with the Salvation Army. All families are screened for eligibility before being accepted into the program. To become a corporate angel, contact Maj. Deborah Colbert at deborah.colbert @uss.salvationarmy.org or call (336) 723-6366, ext. 109 Literacy project to hold info sessions The Augustine Literacy Project, a program of READWS, needs volunteers to serve as tutors to public school students. Information sessions about the program will be held at 9:30 a.m. and 6:30 p.m. Dec. 1 at Grace Presbyterian Church, 360 Hopkins Road, Kernersville. A five-day training session will be held beginning Jan. 5 at Cash Elementary School, 4700 Old Hollow Road, Kernersville. A 10-day training session is scheduled to be held beginning Jan. 23 at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church, 520 Summit St. For more information or to register, email pam @readws.org or call (336) 723-4391, ext. 1509. GriefShare helps deal with the holidays GriefShare will hold a seminar on “Surviving the Holidays” on Dec. 3 at Oaklawn Baptist Church, 3500 Kernersville Road. Sign-in will be at 1 p.m., and the seminar will take place from 1:30 to 3:45 p.m. The registration deadline is Nov. 28. The cost is $5, and each participant will receive a DVD, “Survival Guide” and other handouts. Discussions will explore creative and helpful ideas to make the holiday season less painful. For more information or to register, call (336) 788-2569 or go to www.grief share.org/holidays. GriefShare seminars are sponsored by Shady Grove Wesleyan Church, Glenn View Baptist Church, Oaklawn Baptist Church and the Senior Center of Kernersville. Tax-preparation volunteers needed The Experiment in Self-Reliance needs volunteers to help with its free tax-preparation program. The Forsyth Free Tax Program provides free tax-preparation services for low and moderate income residents at Volunteer Income Tax Assistance sites throughout Forsyth County. The program utilizes volunteer tax preparers who are certified by the Internal Revenue Service. Volunteers will receive training to provide tax help to families who need assistance preparing their tax returns. Training is offered both online and in the classroom. Volunteers will work at one or more of the tax sites according to their availability. Tax sites are generally open during the day, at night and on weekends, with flexible hours. Positions include intake coordinator, tax preparer, quality reviewer and greeter. No prior experience is needed. For more information, contact Delores McCullough at (336) 722-9400, ext. 172, or email delores.mccullough@eisr.org. Walmart Foundation, company give grants Walmart and the Walmart Foundation have awarded more than $694,000 to nonprofit agencies in North Carolina. Communities in Schools of Wilkes County, received a $25,000 grant for its New Century Scholars program. Y-USA/YMCA grants support yearlong meal programs nationwide, providing 15 million meals to 480,000 children through federally reimbursed after-school and summer meal programs. The YMCA of Northwest North Carolina, received a grant for $55,000. ReStores collecting food donations Habitat for Humanity of Forsyth County ReStores are accepting food donations for Second Harvest Food Bank of Northwest North Carolina through Nov. 30. Customers who bring three nonperishable food items will receive a 10 percent discount off their entire purchase; customers who donate six nonperishable food items will get a 20 percent discount.
