Myers is an excellent choice for K-State Chris Cillizza: Trump’s smart flirtation with Romney Connect With Us Email alerts Text alerts Apps C-J staff tweets C-J Instagram C-J Pinterest C-J Facebook Photo & Video Local Video National Video C-J YouTube Slideshows Spotted Jobs Topeka Jobs Post a Job Post a resume Contact Us Homes Buy & Sell Classifieds Home Garage Sales Residences for Rent Estate Tag/Flea Markets Properties Apartments, unfurnished Automobiles Items for Sale Legals C-J Deals Circulars Data Databases Home 2016 Retirement Facilities Daily Record Marriage Licenses Divorces Court Dispositions Court Filings Find Cheap Gas Weather Special Topics Best of Topeka Downtown Topeka Retirement Twist of Fate Volunteer Topeka Top 100 Athletes Crossroads of Freedom Newspapers in Education Calendar of Events Subscriptions All Access digital subscription Subscriber Services Payments Delivery Problems Vacation Hold Rewards Local Store Sales Autos Help Contact Us C-J Staff Media Kit Newsletter - Select -At Home LivingCJ Media Monthly MinuteCJDealsCJOnline Breaking NewsCJOnline Evening HeadlinesCJOnline Morning HeadlinesCJOnline Sports HeadlinesContests & Special Promotionsjobs.cjonline.com Subscribe Posted November 19, 2016 10:52 pm By Morgan Chilson morgan.chilson@cjonline.com Fresh food as close as your local parking lot Deals going down in Topeka parking lots aren’t always illegal. In fact, Topekans are feeding their families with fresh seafood and meats when they meet up with a Zaycon Fresh truck locally. Zaycon Fresh is a farm-to-table supplier of foods, and the Spokane, Wash., company operating nationwide delivers fresh meats and seafood to Topeka. Customers order online and then pick up at a specified time in a local parking lot. CEO Mike Conrad, said the company, was born out of desperation when the economy crashed around 2007 and 2008. “I was in the mortgage business. It wasn’t a good time to be in the mortgage business then,” Conrad said. “I ended up being on welfare, going bankrupt. I ended up losing everything.” As Conrad watched his life disintegrate, so did his brother, who also found himself out of work and on welfare. But the two had a kernel of an idea. Conrad’s brother, J.C. Conrad, who is no longer with the company, had been a butcher at a grocery store in 2001. During that career, he experimented with selling chicken in a 40-pound butcher’s box, and it sold like crazy, Conrad said. “The store freaked out,” he said. “They’d never seen that kind of revenue.” So as the two brothers sat contemplating what they could do to change their fortunes, they decided maybe that concept would work in a broader market. They launched in 2009 and through word of mouth, Excel spreadsheets and hard work, they sold chicken for $1.49 a pound. “We sold 850 cases in two weeks,” Conrad said. “Just word of mouth — people sending us cash and checks in the mail. It was crazy. We didn’t even have a website. We were so excited. We were so broke.” They sold everything from fresh peaches and apples to meat in those early days, but finally settled on meat as their most viable market. “We weren’t even planning on going outside of Spokane, that’s the honest truth,” Conrad said. “We were just trying to pay our bills. Customers started coming to us and asking us, ‘Hey, my mom lives in Portland, Ore. Can you go to her?’ ” They encouraged customers to get a group of people together who would order and they would get a truck delievered there. “Because the market was so bad, people were looking for a deal, especially on meat,” Conrad said. “In June 2010, it hadn’t been six months, we decided we’re going to go to every state with this. We were so dumb, we couldn’t realize that we were going to fail. So we started a campaign called Chicken Across America. Nobody knew who we were.” They reached out to about 850 bloggers online and 450 of them responded that they’d blog about the company for a case of chicken. “We got a website, and my cousin jumped in his truck and delivered chicken from Washington to Maine. I took the south side of the country,” Conrad said. “That was our marketing. That’s how we were going to do it. We had no idea that it would work or wouldn’t work. When you’re on the bottom, there’s nowhere to go but up.” They delivered 28 truckloads of chicken in a week and a half, Conrad recalled. Then economies of scale began to play in the business, and they needed to look at how to deliver meat nationwide. They didn’t own trucks and had no logistics plan, he said. It’s been a challenging success story, and Conrad said he’s learned along the way. The proof is in the sales, which according to Inc. magazine, the Baird investment bank projected to reach $70 million. “Our model is this: We presell everything,” Conrad said. “Then we go to the vendor and we buy the chicken, then we deliver it on a certain day at a certain time, and the people will come pick it up. We’ve got our signs, we put up our cones, we get going. It’s pretty cool. They’ll get in line, we roll up initially with a spreadsheet and we just sign off.” The focus of the company is selling fresh food at reduced prices because of cutting out the middle of the process. Over time, Zaycon morphed from a small business run by family members into a smooth operation needed to handle such extensive sales. The company has a proprietary logistics software that tracks sales, tracks the people who show up and check in and they know where every truck is at all times. If there’s a weight difference in the box — say it was supposed to be 40 pounds but came up 38.8 — it’s credited on the spot, Conrad said. The big sellers are chicken, ground beef, bacon and ham, he said. It’s sold by the case, so it’s not uncommon for people to split a case. The food comes straight from farms, and the chicken is fresh, not frozen. “You get fresh 93/7 ground beef. It’s four to six days old, and it hasn’t been sitting in any warehouse, it’s not waiting to get put into displays,” Conrad said. Topeka customer Alora Mayer has been buying from Zaycon for about a year. She learned about the company from a friend in Kansas City and began splitting boxes of product. Each month different deliveries are made, sometimes of chicken, pork or seafood. “We have yet to get anything that we’ve been disappointed with. The quality that we’ve gotten with Zaycon is incredible,” she said, adding that Red Argentine Shrimp has been a favorite. Although she often will buy a full box to feed her family of four, if it’s something she wants to split, she just sends a note out on Facebook and finds a friend to split the product and price. The company delivers to 48 states with 1,183 locations. Many of their drop-off points are local churches, and they usually donate a case of chicken or whatever they’re delivering to the church, Conrad said. Many of those churches then pass the food on to local pantries. The company has a referral program so customers can get a $5 food credit when their friends buy and then you get $1 every time that person buys, he said. “We just need more customers in every area. It gets easier and cheaper for us to bring the food the larger we are, the bigger the truck,” he said of future growth. “Expansion is really just where we’re at, getting more customers, understanding who we are and what we provide.” In general, Zaycon customers save 30 to 50 percent off of what they would pay for a lesser-quality product at grocery stores, Conrad said. Years later, Conrad is still excited about the company and what it provides to customers. “We did this to pay our bills,” he said, adding that he didn’t understand what would happen. “We have a net promoter score of 82, which is how excited your customers are. If you look at Walmart, they’re under 50. If you go on our Facebook page, you’ll see people raving about buying chicken. It’s the weirdest thing.” The growth in the business the first three years was over 1,000 percent, he said. “That’s easy because if you go from nothing to $1,000 …” he said, laughing. “We’re growing about 30 to 40 percent almost every year.” Conrad’s cousin Adam Kremin has been a part of it throughout its tenuous beginnings to its current success. J.C. Conrad left to pursue another career, Conrad said, and, frankly, it was stressful. “We were growing too fast. There were many points in this business, we were like how are we going to pay the bills,” he said. “Sometimes the growth is scary because you’re like, holy hell, how do I pay for all of this? I can’t keep up.” There were many learning opportunities along the way. They became convinced of the need for technology after a Boise, Idaho, event that drew 1,600 cars to pick up food. “It wasn’t automated. We had four lines of cars,” Conrad said. “I had to hire two cops, one for incoming traffic, one for outgoing. It was a three-hour event, with 40 helpers. We had to consolidate all those spreadsheets to figure out who picked up, who didn’t pick up.” So they automated. And continued to grow. “I couldn’t figure out why people were buying our chicken, why they loved it so much,” he said. “The reason they like our food is it’s so fresh. Straight from the farm to the event. We have no warehouses. Unless you have a chicken coop, you’re not getting it any fresher, I’m telling you.” Advertisement Most Popular News Fri, 11/18/2016 - 23:22 Rep. Mike Pompeo, a Wichita Republican, chosen by Donald Trump to head the CIA News Fri, 11/18/2016 - 11:48 USD 501 names Jardine Elementary principal News Fri, 11/18/2016 - 23:22 Kansas judicial branch requests $20 million for salary increases News Fri, 11/18/2016 - 20:00 Advisors Excel, Payless donate coats and shoes to Sheldon Head Start students   View all Local Store Sales » Advertisement More Sun, 11/20/2016 - 09:50 Today’s weather for Nov. 20, 2016 Topeka weather for Sunday and Monday should be fairly normal for November, going off of figures by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric... Local stores set to start holiday shopping season Jeff Barron , Reporter 7:42 a.m. EST November 20, 2016 Buy Photo Susie Jones, right, owner of Susie’s Gifts, assists customers shopping during Black Friday in 2011. (Photo: Gazette File Photo)Buy Photo CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Central Ohio shoppers will soon be heading to start their holiday shopping. Many will no doubt start on Thanksgiving or the day after on Black Friday. Here's a look at the hours some major retailers in the Lancaster and Chillicothe areas will be open: Chillicothe area: Sears at 1075 N. Broad St will open from 6 p.m. to midnight on Thanksgiving and will be open from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Kohl's at 45 River Trace will open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving and stay open until midnight on Black Friday. JCPenney will open at 3 p.m. Thanksgiving and remain open until 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Elder-Beerman at 1080 N. Broad St. will openat 5 p.m. Thanksgiving and stay open until 11 p.m. on Black Friday. Dick's Sporting Goods at 1251 N. Broad St. will openat 6 p.m. Thanksgiving and close at 2 a.m. It will open at 5 a.m. on Black Friday and close at 11 p.m. Kmart at 1470 N. Broad St. will open at 6 a.m. Thanksgiving and stay open through Black Friday. Sam's Club at 1270 N. Broad St. is closed on Thanksgiving and open from 7 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. on Black Friday. Walmart at 85 River Trace Lane will be open 24 hours on both Thanksgiving and Black Friday. Lowe's at 867 N. Broad St. is closed on Thanksgiving and will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Black Friday. Tanger Outlets at 8000 Factory Shops Blvd in Jeffersonville will be open from 6 p.m. to midnight on Thanksgiving and from 12 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Black Friday. Central Ohio area Target at 1300 River Valley Blvd. in Lancaster will be open from 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving until 10 p.m. on Black Friday. The River Valley Mall at 1635 River Valley Circle South will open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving and will not close until 10 p.m. on Black Friday. The Polaris Fashion Place at 1500 Polaris Parkway in Columbus will be open from 6 p.m. to 1 a.m. Thanksgiving and from 6 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. on Black Friday. Also, stores at the Easton Town Center at 160 Easton Town Center in Columbus are opening at several different times. Visit www.eastontowncenter.com/thanksgiving-weekend for a listing of shopping hours. jbarron@lancastereaglegazette.com 740-681-4340 Twitter: @JeffDBarron CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Rodrigo Duterte meets Vladimir Putin—terrible news for the New World Order NEO – Rebel Unity Fails Amid Aleppo’s Fall Britain to continue arms sales to Saudi Arabia Your Radiation This Week No 81 and 82 ‹ › Dr. Kevin Barrett, a Ph.D. Arabist-Islamologist, is one of America’s best-known critics of the War on Terror. He is Host of TRUTH JIHAD RADIO; a hard driving weekly LIVE call in radio show. He also has appeared many times on Fox, CNN, PBS and other broadcast outlets, and has inspired feature stories and op-eds in the New York Times, the Christian Science Monitor, the Chicago Tribune, and other leading publications. Dr. Barrett has taught at colleges and universities in San Francisco, Paris, and Wisconsin, where he ran for Congress in 2008. He currently works as a nonprofit organizer, author, and talk radio host. View Latest Posts >>> If Trump does these ten things he’ll be the greatest president ever By Kevin Barrett on November 19, 2016 And hell will freeze over By Kevin Barrett, Veterans Today Editor (Watch False Flag Weekly News above, and click HERE for story links…and HERE to subscribe to TruthJihad.com and support my shows. -KB) Everybody’s arguing about Trump. Families are split. Couples are at each others’ throats. Racial, ethnic, and religious tensions are in the air. Here at VT the comment section has been in an uproar for months. I’ve been arguing about Trump with some smart people, people I respect. I just pre-recorded an interview with James Petras, an accomplished leftist anti-Empire sociologist and contributor to my False Flag Trilogy. He has positive things to say about Trump. So does Robert David Steele, the whistleblowing former CIA Clandestine Services Officer who’s a prime force behind my new book Orlando False Flag. Steele actually believes Trump might push through the Election Reform Act of 2016.  Listen to my brand-new interview with Steele for the details. Petras, the radical leftist, and Steele, the reformist conservative Republican, are both brilliant. They are two of the greatest minds of our time. But I suspect they are wrong about Trump. The Simpsons got it right when they predicted Trump’s campaign slogan would be: “America, you can be my ex-wife.” Many of his supporters, especially the alternative media types, are going to be falling out of love with this guy real fast. If you’re paying attention, you’re already disillusioned. Some of the headlines from this week’s False Flag Weekly News include: Hillary Actually Won – Professor Mark Crispin Miller Reveals Election Fraud! Why isn’t Hillary contesting Trump’s weird “win”? Is it because she stole “her” nomination? Trump transition committee run by Kosher Nostra boss Adelson, 9/11 criminal Eisenberg (who handed WTC to Silverstein) The Israeli Right Wing Is Delighted by Trump’s Win — and Why That’s So Dangerous  Trump Picks Anti-Muslim Extremist Michael Flynn To Be National Security Adviser To be fair, there is possible good news on the Syria front. But the overall gestalt does not look good. The same people who were convinced that Jade Helm was a plan to lock up millions of dissidents in Wal-Mart are the most fanatical Trump supporters.  They are being scammed by exactly the same people – Bibi’s propaganda team in the fake alternative media – once again. Here is my to-do list for Trump. If he does any of these things, I will eat crow. If he does all of them I will eat a whole flock. Expose the truth about 9/11, which is that it was a neocon coup designed to unleash Islamophobia to benefit Israel. Reinstate the Constitution by repealing all post-9/11 police state legislation and pushing through draconian restrictions on all forms of spying, search and seizure, etc. Push through Steele’s Election Reform Act, ending the corrupt two-party duopoly. Close down US military bases worldwide and return to a defend-the-borders posture. Use the savings to rebuild America’s infrastructure. Force big corporations to bring manufacturing jobs back to the US. (If he leaves office in 2024 with the percentage of made-in-USA stuff equivalent to what it was in, say, 1970, he will have succeeded.) End the Fed and print honest, Constitutional currency. Pass and enforce real anti-trust legislation so there can be no more monopolies or collusive trade practices, period. Push through the Constitutional amendment that would be needed to end private funding of political campaigns by the rich and special interests. Bust up big media into thousands of much smaller pieces, and use antitrust laws to keep them small. The above list is pretty much what it would take to “Make America great again.” Good luck with that one, Mr. Trump. I don’t think you have the slightest interest in actually fixing any of the country’s biggest problems. But I hope you prove me wrong. Related Posts: Donald Trump: “Bombs were used on the World Trade Center!” FFWN: Dallas police shootings a false flag? President Barack Obama: Give Trump a chance Should the military overthrow Trump? Myers is an excellent choice for K-State Chris Cillizza: Trump’s smart flirtation with Romney Connect With Us Email alerts Text alerts Apps C-J staff tweets C-J Instagram C-J Pinterest C-J Facebook Photo & Video Local Video National Video C-J YouTube Slideshows Spotted Jobs Topeka Jobs Post a Job Post a resume Contact Us Homes Buy & Sell Classifieds Home Garage Sales Residences for Rent Estate Tag/Flea Markets Properties Apartments, unfurnished Automobiles Items for Sale Legals C-J Deals Circulars Data Databases Home 2016 Retirement Facilities Daily Record Marriage Licenses Divorces Court Dispositions Court Filings Find Cheap Gas Weather Special Topics Best of Topeka Downtown Topeka Retirement Twist of Fate Volunteer Topeka Top 100 Athletes Crossroads of Freedom Newspapers in Education Calendar of Events Subscriptions All Access digital subscription Subscriber Services Payments Delivery Problems Vacation Hold Rewards Local Store Sales Autos Help Contact Us C-J Staff Media Kit Newsletter - Select -At Home LivingCJ Media Monthly MinuteCJDealsCJOnline Breaking NewsCJOnline Evening HeadlinesCJOnline Morning HeadlinesCJOnline Sports HeadlinesContests & Special Promotionsjobs.cjonline.com Subscribe Posted November 19, 2016 09:47 pm - Updated November 19, 2016 11:18 pm By Justin Wingerter justin.wingerter@cjonline.com American Radical: John Booker Jr. and the FBI plot to imprison him Part One A 2009 Topeka West High School yearbook contains a photo of John Booker Jr. as a freshman. (Emily DeShazer/The Capital-Journal) On Oct. 8, 2014, a man calling himself Omar walked into a Dillons grocery store in southwest Topeka. He said he was Iraqi, working as an air conditioner repairman and looking for a mosque to attend. More immediately, he was looking for a particular Dillons employee: John Booker Jr. Short and bookish in a kufi cap and glasses, Booker wasn’t the type to attract many visitors at work or outside of it. He spoke softly, rarely deviating from a topic of choice: his Muslim faith. Just two years removed from high school, Booker had no friends, no social life and only periodic contact with his parents. Omar’s car that day was a rental with out-of-state plates. Booker hopped in but, fearful of government surveillance, insisted the two speak in the backseat. He hid his phone in Omar’s glovebox as they spoke. Over the next six months, Omar picked up Booker often, always in a rental car with out-of-state plates. They ate at Red Lobster, attended mosque services and drove around. Their conversations centered on Islam and, increasingly, on its most violent, radical adherents. Booker’s fears of FBI surveillance were well-founded. He was being followed. His words were being recorded and transcribed. His actions were being monitored, his motives probed, his compliance sought. And his newfound friend, Omar, was not who he claimed to be. Omar was an FBI informant. In the two years since he left Topeka West, Booker had been radicalized online, seduced by conspiracy theories and inspired by jihadists. A promise on social media to wage jihad and die had ended his military career. A Topeka imam's guidance had helped stabilize the troubled young man. Omar was there to test his willingness to harm hundreds, if not thousands, of innocent people. It was a test Booker would fail. With a small loan from his lone, developmentally disabled friend, Booker set out to bomb Fort Riley. In phone interviews and a dozen letters sent from his cell at CCA Leavenworth, the federal prison where he's sentenced to spend the next three decades, Booker recalled it all. “I was always solo my entire life,” he said. The maximum-security prison is a stark departure from a tree-lined suburban street 70 miles to the southwest where Booker was raised and his parents still live in a nondescript off-white Topeka home. Booker was a Christian who, in his teenage years, began studying autodidactically to become a Catholic priest. While perusing world religions, he became convinced that all but one glorifies an idol. The only true religion, Booker came to believe, is Islam. “Most people my age were watching music videos. I was watching lectures on Allah." By then he was a junior at Topeka West High School. Awkward, shy and bipolar, Booker’s strict adherence to religion further alienated him. There were few Muslims at the school and the recent convert was unimpressed with those he found, considering them too moderate in their actions. “Most people my age were watching music videos. I was watching lectures on Allah,” Booker recalls. He didn’t drink alcohol or date. He didn’t go to strip clubs, as some of his classmates did, or obsess over women. The dreams and desires of other teenagers confused him. Unable to relate to those around him, Booker grew increasingly insular. He also gravitated toward the military, enrolling in Topeka West’s Junior ROTC program during all four years of high school. A photo of cadets shows Booker looking out of place, noticeably shorter than everyone around him, but stoic in his spotless uniform. In another, Booker smiles widely as he and fellow cadets deliver gifts to foster children. In a Topeka Capital-Journal article about the gift-giving, written in 2011, Booker said helping children brought him joy: “I can’t have a good Christmas if they don’t.” John Booker Jr. can be seen on the far right of the front row in this JROTC Raider Team group yearbook photo from his senior year. (2012 Topeka West yearbook) Life was less cheery after high school. He moved to Kansas City, Mo., where he struggled to find work. He turned down employment opportunities that did not closely adhere to his faith, such as jobs that required him to handle alcohol. “I was homeless at times in Kansas City but happy. I was living for Islam, living for Allah,” he said. In Kansas City, his views on Islam hardened. He became fascinated with conspiracy theories, collecting government documents he believed proved his premises. One such theory is a popular one on the internet: that the federal government orchestrated the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. “I believed what everybody else believed at first. Then I began reading a lot of documents,” Booker said. “I have a lot of conspiracy theories and I realized 9/11 was not done by Muslims.” It was in Kansas City that the messages of al-Qaida first resonated with the recent high school graduate. He would spend hours online studying martyrs and their methods. But an imam at the mosque he was attending made his opposition to radical Islam clear, going so far as to order Booker removed from his mosque. Booker, who says the imam “is not a very good Muslim,” claimed the mosque belonged to Allah, not the religious leader, as he was being escorted out. At a second mosque in Kansas City, which Booker declines to name, congregants also disagreed with his support of al-Qaida but allowed him to stay and pray. He became a devout attendee. His contact with family and friends lessened and his attraction to radical groups grew. “They were the only mujahideen fighting for Islam at that time,” he said of al-Qaida. “They were fighting for Allah, fighting for Islam.” Booker began calling himself Mohammad Abdullah Hassan, the name of a late 19th century Muslim leader. Known as the “Mad Mullah” by British forces in Somalia, Hassan waged an unsuccessful 20-year war against Christians in a crusade for religious and political independence on the Horn of Africa. In letters from Leavenworth, Booker alternates between signing off as “John” and “Mohammad.” As the calendar turned from 2012 to 2013, and then 2014, Booker’s motive for joining the military flipped. He no longer wanted to fight for the United States. Convinced that his government was the enemy of Islam at home and abroad, Booker now wanted to fight against it. “All of us have to stand on something,” he said. “That’s what I stood on — dying.” In May of 2014, a 22-year-old American citizen, Moner Mohammad Abusalha, drove a bomb-laden truck into a Syrian army stronghold, killing 37. But before he did, he narrated a video that called on fellow American Muslims to “join the caravan of jihad and martyrdom.” Abusalha grew up in a gated oceanfront Florida community far from the turbulent Middle East where he would die. When Booker saw the video, he was galvanized. “He escaped America to join the Syrian rebels, to fight against Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president. This story and speech he did inspired me, and also his act of doing a suicide bombing,” Booker wrote in a letter from Leavenworth. An undated frame grab shows American suicide attacker Moner Mohammad Abusalha, the first American to carry out a suicide attack in Syria's civil war. (AP Photo/Manara al-Bayda) Booker gravitated toward American jihadists. In the same letter, he fondly recalls Anwar al-Awkali’s lectures on the blessings of martyrdom, paradise and hellfire. Awlaki, who was born in New Mexico, inspired several terrorist attacks, including a 2009 shooting at Fort Hood that Booker would later praise, before being killed in a drone strike in Yemen in 2011. Several months after Abusalha’s bombing, the Islamic State released “The Flames of War,” a 55-minute video narrated by an unidentified American. It was propaganda portrayed as a documentary calling on Muslims the world over to “unite under one call, one banner, one leader.” The call was jihad, the banner the IS flag and the leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. During their time together, Booker and Omar watched both videos. Booker wanted to join IS in Syria, he told Omar, and he wanted help getting there. As they watched a video about suicide bombers, Booker determined that was his calling. That was how he wanted to die. On Oct. 10, 2014, just two days after meeting Omar, Booker spoke openly to him about his past as an Army recruit and al-Qaida supporter, according to FBI task force officer Mark Enghold. “I was in jihad before, okay. I got captured,” he told Omar. “Okay, a long story short, the people at the (mosque) don’t like me because I support al-Qaida openly. I’m not afraid; I was captured before…I was captured by FBI before…because I was with al-Qaida.” Seven months earlier, on March 9, 2014, Halima Bwanadi received a strange phone call. A man speaking Swahili said “hodi," or hello. When she responded in Swahili, the voice on the other end became confused. Switching to English, he said, “I’m gonna kill Mama Medina” then abruptly hung up. The name of Bwanadi’s mother is Medina Mohammed. When Bwanadi and her mother returned home that night to their northeast Kansas City apartment, it had been burglarized. A window, usually closed, was now open. Lights they always turned off were now on. Two police officers scanned the apartment, found it vacant, and escorted the women through the rooms in search of missing belongings. They determined nothing had been stolen. The Bwanadis believed someone was trying to frighten them. When the officers asked the women if they knew who might have burglarized the apartment, Amina Bwanadi, a 15-year-old girl, spoke up. Booker had lived with the family up until a few months before the burglary, when he and Mohammed had a falling out. Booker was told to leave. This, according to Amina, infuriated him. Booker called Amina to tell her he was joining the U.S. Army to wage jihad from within and the Bwanadis, moderate Muslims uninterested in Booker’s radicalism, had cast him aside. Booker was never charged in the case, according to Missouri court records, and he vehemently denies having any role in the alleged break-in. At a recruiting station in Kansas City, Booker enlisted in the U.S. Army in February of 2014. Before he reported to basic training on April 7, he explained his new motive on Facebook, telling the world what he had told Amina Bwanadi. “I will soon be leaving you forever so goodbye! I’m going to wage jihad and hopes (sic) that I die,” a March 15 post stated. “Getting ready to be killed in jihad is a HUGE adrenaline rush!! I am so nervous. NOT because I’m scared to die but I am eager to meet my lord,” he wrote four days later, on March 19. In less than two years in Kansas City, Booker had warped dramatically from a quiet Junior ROTC high school graduate to an aspiring terrorist determined to attack the United States. But much to his frustration, not a single Muslim he knew agreed with his militant mindset. Booker, once again, was alone. Prior to the second he clicked the “post” button on Facebook that mid-March day in 2014, there is no evidence in court records, police reports or Topeka Public School disciplinary records that Booker had a criminal history. Though boastful of his terroristic desires and imprisonment, Booker says he had no experience with crimes, petty or otherwise. The only mention of Booker in Topeka police records is on March 20, 2014. At 2 p.m. that day, officers went to his apartment in the 2900 block of S.W. Arnold. A non-criminal incident report written by a TPD officer is, like many government documents pertaining to Booker, heavily redacted. He was interviewed that afternoon by FBI agents, who asked about the Facebook posts. Booker, according to the FBI, flatly told the agents he enlisted in the Army to kill American soldiers, either during basic training or after. “The defendant clarified that he did not intend to kill ‘privates,’ but that he instead wanted to target someone with power,” a plea agreement states. “The defendant also said that he did not intend to use large guns, but instead a small gun or a sword.” Recounting the FBI interview two years later, Booker often refers to it as “being captured.” When speaking to other Muslims, he would brag that he was taken captive by the United States for his support of al-Qaida, a boast that made Muslims at the Islamic Center of Topeka uncomfortable. “They didn’t like me, didn’t like al-Qaida. They told me ‘we don’t agree.’ They gave me different looks,” Booker recalls. In a deep and authoritative baritone, Omar Hazim, imam at the Topeka Islamic Center, speaks in condemnation of the Islamic State at his mosque. When the Prophet Muhammad refers to jihad he is referring to a struggle inside oneself, Hazim teaches. That struggle, the struggle against the evil of one’s soul, is the only true jihad. Imam Omar Hazim of the Topeka Islamic Center. (File photo/The Capital-Journal) On March 20, 2014, Hazim was at home when he received a phone call just before midnight. An FBI agent told him about their detainment of a young man and wanted to know if Hazim knew him. The name didn’t sound familiar but he offered to help anyway. When agents brought Booker to Hazim the next day, he recognized him as an occasional attendee at the Islamic Center. The FBI’s hope was that Hazim, through counseling, could moderate Booker. “They thought at that time he could be salvaged and his mind could be changed,” Hazim recalls. Booker “seemed like he was sincere about religion but was more or less confused." “I didn’t really see any anger in him. I saw confusion in him. He was convinced before I met him that because of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan — he felt those were completely wrong — he had an obligation to try to fight that himself.” The radicalism Booker had instilled in himself through the internet during his time in Kansas City left little room for moderating voices. He openly disputed Hazim’s definition of jihad, believing instead that it refers to holy war. During discussions on the Quran, Booker would stand up and walk around, drifting aimlessly in body and mind. FBI agents and Hazim took Booker to Stormont Vail West, the hospital’s behavioral health center. He was admitted for two weeks but no one could force him to stay, not Hazim or the FBI. The imam attempted to have him admitted at Osawatomie State Hospital but, plagued by overcrowding, the staff there let him go. He received treatment at Valeo Behavioral Health Center and the Islamic Center paid for some of his medication. Sometimes it was clear to Hazim that Booker was not swallowing the pills. “I didn’t really see any anger in him. I saw confusion in him." Over the course of several months, Hazim says, Booker took to him. He respected the imam and began listening more intently. The stubbornness waned slightly and, when he was taking medications, so too did Booker’s wandering. In late March of 2014, the FBI and 902nd Military Intelligence Group issued an alert about Booker to law enforcement and military agencies in Kansas “to inform and protect officers who may encounter this individual or others exhibiting the same aspirations." The next time the FBI made contact with Booker was when Omar walked into Dillons that October. When they talked one month later, in November of 2014, Omar gave Booker some good news. A cousin of his knew how to transport Americans to Syria. But was Booker up for the fight? The Islamic State wouldn’t accept just anybody, Omar told him. “I will kill any kuffar,” Booker responded, using an Arabic term for non-Muslims. “I will follow any place...if I was with (IS) and they said, ‘look, we are going to the White House right now’…I would go with them without any question.” In Booker’s recounting of his time with Omar, the FBI informant was the only Islamic State supporter at first. Booker said he proudly supported al-Qaida at the time but knew nothing of IS until Omar introduced him to "The Flames of War." After that, he was hooked. “The reason why it resonated with me is because I mainly was attracted by the establishment of the caliphate and Islamic State government and also the variety of Muslims all over the world were answering the call and joining,” Booker said. There is a dispute between Enghold, the FBI agent, and the young man himself over how Booker arrived at the idea of bombing Fort Riley. In Booker’s version of events, he was “100 percent” entrapped and “tricked” by Omar, knew nothing of IS and never would have considered a bomb plot if not pushed by the FBI. In Enghold’s version, Booker desperately desired to curry favor with the terrorist group, proposing several options for how he would do so. “The decision to do the suicide bombing was made after the FBI agent induced me to do the research on it and (Omar) highly recommended it,” Booker recalled. By the final months of 2014, Booker had boiled his life down to its bare essentials. He worked full-time, first at Dillons and later at a west Topeka Wal-Mart, and walked miles to pray at the Topeka Islamic Center. Despite his friendlessness, Booker said he enjoyed helping Dillons customers, especially elderly women. Hazim, the imam, found he was powerless to stop Booker’s radical leanings. As he taught moderation and a peaceful definition of jihad, Omar preached hatred and violence. “It was a struggle between what I was trying to teach him and the informant the FBI gave him. The young man was divided in his head,” Hazim recalls. The FBI told Hazim about the undercover sting operation, which, they said, was designed to get Booker off the streets before he met actual terrorists with an actual bomb. When Booker and Omar met again in mid-December, they began discussing ways for Booker to impress IS and join its ranks. One plan, according to the FBI, was to kill U.S. Army soldiers with guns and grenades at a military base. Another was to capture a high-ranking officer and force him, on video, to announce the arrival of IS in America. A third plan called for Booker to create a video announcing he would slaughter U.S. Army soldiers one by one in the streets. “It was a struggle between what I was trying to teach him and the informant the FBI gave him. The young man was divided in his head." There is no evidence that Booker had the wherewithal to accomplish any of this. He had no gun, no vehicle, no access to military bases and no experience or training with explosives. Not only would he need a list of bomb-making materials and instructions on how to obtain them, he also needed someone to construct the bomb, arm the bomb, give him a vehicle and show him where to go. Booker had the motive, but not the means, for martyrdom. He also had few expendable funds while working low-wage jobs at grocery and department stores. That's where Alexander Blair came in. Born with a heart defect, Alex was adopted by Jane and Thomas Blair when he was three days old. His seventh chromosome was missing, leaving him with scoliosis and a rare developmental disorder, Williams syndrome, defined by learning disabilities and developmental delays coupled with high levels of friendliness and affability. The result is a kind young man with rosy pink cheeks who craves social contact but often alienates strangers with excessive conversation and eye contact. “Sometimes I think we did too much for him growing up,” Jane Blair recalls. Her son did not walk or talk until he was three and required surgeries to his eyes and back. When the Blairs were told swimming could hasten his development, they installed an in-ground pool and took him to the Menninger Foundation, where he was further diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. At school, Blair hugged his special education teachers and bus drivers but was bullied by fellow students. Beginning at age eight and lasting into adulthood, he paid people to be his friend. He nearly committed suicide in high school, placing a loaded gun to his right temple and pulling the hammer back but not pressing the trigger. Blair enjoyed video games but had an aversion to some of their more violent moments. He played the infamously violent “Grand Theft Auto” series but refused to shoot innocent people in the game. He opted against playing other first-person shooter games, such as “Call of Duty.” Like Booker, Blair considers himself an independent person, in his words a “nomad by spirit.” He changed churches six times in a dozen years, moving on every time he felt uncomfortable, which was often. He gave Hinduism and Buddhism a try but they didn’t stick. His interest in Islam lasted just a few months in early 2015 and was due, in large part, to the religion’s insistence on praying five times each day, a routine Blair found soothing. In a dark irony, Blair sought out Islam in an attempt to reduce his Islamophobia and, as he later told a psychiatrist, to “recognize that not all Muslims are terrorists.” Terrorists were “stupid asses,” according to Blair, and similar to Adolph Hitler or the Ku Klux Klan. Stephen Peterson, a psychiatrist who interviewed Blair for five hours, said he has auditory experiences that seem like hallucinations. They accompany Blair’s three personalities: “Alex,” a protector who helps him feel safe, “Evan,” described as a passionate lover, and his dark side: “Blair.” Blair, according to Peterson’s patient, is “bat s--- crazy and scary.” Blair enlisted and served in the U.S. military before being medically discharged from the Air Force due to his scoliosis and anxiety. His conversion to Islam came in January 2015 at the Topeka Islamic Center. It was there that he met Booker and became the young man’s only friend. “Did I like it? No, I didn’t. But, he asked me for help. I helped him.” Beyond their newfound faith, the two shared loneliness brought on by medical conditions. Booker has bipolar disorder, though he rejects suggestions by some that he is schizophrenic as well. For Blair, it is Williams syndrome. Marisa Fisher, an assistant professor of psychology at Michigan State University and leading expert on Williams syndrome, says the disorder’s effects are problematic for patients. Their overwhelming need for friendship makes them susceptible to victimization. They go along with dangerous ideas. “They don’t want to hurt someone’s feelings or seem rude,” Fisher said, a reference to what Peterson calls Blair’s “puppy syndrome” or tendency to latch on to those who show him positive feedback. In a 2015 study, Fisher and co-authors wrote, “The tendency to approach strangers increases the likelihood that the individual will engage a stranger with ill intentions or the individual may be more willing to walk away with a stranger who presents a lure.” Within months of meeting Booker, Blair had been lured by both his new friend and Omar, who he did not know. Though he made it clear to Booker that he had no interest in jihad, Blair had a difficult time saying no to other requests. “Did I like it? No, I didn’t,” he later told federal agents. “But, he asked me for help. I helped him.” Editor’s note: This is the first story in a two-part series. The second story can be read in print and online Monday. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Best apps to get Black Friday deals Marc Saltzman , USA TODAY 12:31 p.m. EST November 19, 2016 Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share Marc Saltzman delivers this week's Surf Report breaking down the best apps to help you navigate Black Friday deals. Rather than use your real credit card while shopping online, SudoPay helps you create an anonymous, virtual card to use. (Photo: SudoPay) Calling in sick on November 25? You’re not alone. Bargain hunters might just develop a nasty head cold on Black Friday to take advantage of slashed prices ahead of the holiday season. If you’re looking to buy gifts for family, friends, and coworkers, or want to treat yourself to something new, there are deals to be had on Black Friday and Cyber Monday. To help get the best price possible, there are a few “must have” shopping apps to download from Google Play (for Android devices) or App Store (for iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch). Whether you’re shopping at retail or the “endless aisles” at online stores, the following are a few of my favorites. Flipp A flyer and coupon aggregator, this app helps sniff out the best deals near you.  (Photo: Flipp) Consider it the ultimate flyer and coupon app: Flipp lets you use your fingertip to flip through the flyers of all your local stores – whether it’s an electronics retailer, clothing store, home improvement center, department store chain, kids place, or supermarket – and you’ll be able to see and save the latest deals, add items to a shopping list, digitally clip coupons to show the cashier, or tap and hold a product to get more information on it. It’s a lot cleaner and more convenient than going through all the paper flyers and coupons we receive every week. Plus, you can also do a keyword search on something you want, browse by category, or use a touch slider to only see more aggressive discounts. Flipp is also a loyalty card holder, so you can load all those rewards cards and then leave the plastic at home. Ebates Earn cash back on places you’ll shop at anyway. Ebates supports thousands of popular stores and marketplaces like Amazong, eBay and Groupon.  (Photo: Ebates) Saving money is great, but what if you could earn cash back by shopping? That’s the concept behind Ebates, an app and website that gives you a percentage back of your purchase every time you shop online through participating retailers and marketplaces – and there are more than 2,000 of them. To get going, sign up for a free account, and then start shopping where you would normally – places like Amazon, Macys, Kohls, Walmart, eBay, JCPenney, and Groupon, to name just a few – and you’ll start accumulating cash that can be sent to you via check or deposited into a PayPal account. Each store offers a different cash back percentage, typically ranging from 2% to 6 %, but expect the percentage to climb as high as 40% this time of year. Ebates says stores pay them a commission for sending you there – so you always need to start by launching the Ebates app or visiting the website – and then Ebates shares a portion of the fee with you. SudoPay/SudoApp SudoPay: Rather than use your real credit card while shopping online, SudoPay helps you create an anonymous, virtual card to use.  (Photo: SudoPay) Launched just in time for the holiday shopping season, SudoPay creates a virtual MasterCard for you to shop online with – based on a credit or debit card you already have enabled through Apple Pay – so you can buy what you like without fear of data breaches or hacks that could lead to identity theft. Available for iPhone users but with an Android version in the works, SudoPay also lets you customize your virtual card’s appearance and the dollar amount, ranging from $10 to $1000, and if you like, you can also create and text someone a personalized gift card to their phone, even if they don't have SudoPay. To use SudoPay and its companion app, SudoApp, costs are about 4.5% of the total amount of the virtual card you create – a small price to pay for peace of mind while giving out a credit card number to online merchants over Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and the holidays. eBay Bid, buy, and sell on eBay and its redesigned app for mobile devices.  (Photo: Ebay Corp.) Don’t forget about online marketplaces, such as eBay, and its newly-updated app makes it easy to browse, search, buy, and sell. Contrary to popular belief, not all goods on eBay are “previously enjoyed” – in fact, roughly 80% are brand new, says the company — and if you don't want to bid for something, many items can be purchased outright (look for the “Buy It Now” icon). It’s also easy to find specific deals tied to Black Friday and Cyber Monday, including discounts on top brands and with free shipping, plus there’s an improved search feature, personalized recommendations based on your shopping habits, and the ability to follow your favorite sellers to see when the products you want are available and on sale. If you’re selling stuff – perhaps to make cash for holiday shopping – you can now use your phone to scan the product’s barcode to help auto-create a listing. Follow Marc on Twitter: @marc_saltzman. E-mail him at askmarcsaltzman@gmail.com. 66 CONNECTTWEET 24 LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/2fFPj5j

Rabon said he yielded only 100 acres of 700 acres of cotton this year because of the wind and rain from the storm. The wind blew most of the crop from the plants. The rain forced the rest on the plants to hard lock, not blossom, so it was a loss too. The rain forced the rest on the plants to hard lock, not blossom, so it was a loss too. (Janet Blackmon Morgan/The Sun News via AP) Janet Blackmon Morgan Disasters for county farmers create uncertain future ADVANCE FOR SATURDAY, NOV. 18 AND THEREAFTER - In a Friday, Nov 11, 2016 photo, Ronald Rabon of Double R Farms in Aynor, SC., surveys the damage to his cotton crop from Hurricane Matthew. Rabon said he yielded only 100 acres of 700 acres of cotton this year because of the wind and rain from the storm. The wind blew most of the crop from the plants. The rain forced the rest on the plants to hard lock, not blossom, so it was a loss too.(Janet Blackmon Morgan/The Sun News via AP) Janet Blackmon Morgan Disasters for county farmers create uncertain future ADVANCE FOR SATURDAY, NOV. 18 AND THEREAFTER - A Friday, Nov 11, 2016 photo shows a cotton plant damaged by Hurricane Matthew at Ronald Rabon's Double R Farms in Aynor, SC. Rabon said he yielded only 100 acres of 700 acres of cotton this year because of the wind and rain from the storm. The wind blew most of the crop from the plants. The rain forced the rest on the plants to hard lock, not blossom, so it was a loss too. (Janet Blackmon Morgan/The Sun News via AP) Posted: Saturday, November 19, 2016 6:50 pm Disasters for county farmers create uncertain future Associated Press | AYNOR, S.C. (AP) — The Double R Farm has produced abundant crops for four generations of Rabon family farmers here, and despite the double whammy of record rains during the October harvest last year and last month's hurricane, they are determined to weather the hardship. "I'll do whatever I gotta do, even if it means I'm worn out and broke," says Ronald Rabon. "But if I make it this year, it will take a miracle from the Lord." Tropical storm-force winds and 12 inches of rain from Hurricane Matthew battered 700 acres of his cotton just as the bolls began to open, resulting in hardlock that made picking nearly impossible. They were able to salvage about 100 acres, mostly from farm lands tucked among wooded areas protected from the wind. Instead of 1,400 bales of cotton this year, the Rabons will likely end up with about 450 bales. "I've lost more money than I made in two years," Rabon said. The Rabons and farmers across the state were hit by a drought last year, and after months of praying for rain, the heavens opened in early October and dropped about 14 inches in 24 hours. Farmers in Horry County racked up $9 million in damages, while statewide the amount topped $530 million. William Hardee III, Clemson University's area agronomy agent for Horry County, said farmers were on the path for a perfect crop this year, until Matthew hit. Cotton was hit; soybeans and peanut crops were also severely damaged, Hardee said. "We needed a perfect year to make up for last year, but this took our chance away," Hardee said. Although the final damage assessment has not been tallied, Hardee said it appears that the hurricane will not exceed last year's drought and record flood destruction of crops. "It's not doom and gloom, not the devastation we saw last year, but it was bad for a lot of folks, worse for some others," Hardee said. Out of 600 acres of cotton planted last year, the Rabons salvaged 200 acres that amounted to less than 350 bales. "Now I'm telling you, it's been tough," said the patriarch of the family, 86-year-old Dock Rabon. Gov. Nikki Haley vetoed $40 million in farm aid this spring, calling it an industry bailout, prompting a backlash from farmers and lawmakers who voted to overturn her decision. That funding eventually paid about 25 percent of Rabon's losses, and he was forced to refinance the 1,200 acre farm. "I expected to make it up this year, but the cotton hit the dirt. And what didn't fall, hardlocked. It ain't looking good," Rabon said. Nearly 800 farmers in Horry County have applied for assistance from the U.S. Department of Agriculture because of damage caused by Hurricane Matthew. However, direct payments for damaged crops were eliminated in the 2014 Farm Bill, so aid is limited to emergency conservation problems, property damage, debris removal, leveling land or repairing fences for livestock. State agriculture officials are still assessing the recent damage and officials are mum on whether any financial assistance will be forthcoming. "Two years in a row is rough," says Jared Martin, who estimates he lost half of his 300-acre peanut crops due to Hurricane Matthew. "We've got to have some help, I can't handle no more," said Martin. "Insurance don't pay nothing, and our government just ain't helping." Martin and his father at the D and J Farm managed to pay their bills last year, with only $2,000 left to split between them. This year, Martin says he will break even. "I'm working all year for nothing," Martin said. Rabon and Martin are uncertain about their future in farming, and Martin isn't willing to commit to planting crops next year. "All I know is farming, but I guess I could go to Walmart and shake some hands," Rabon said. Rabon has already reached out to state and federal lawmakers to let them know the severity of the damage, but he's counting on private refinancing to pull him through to farm another year. "In all the years I've farmed, I've never had to call my congressperson or governor for help, we've always made a living," Rabon said. Rabon says he's not looking for a free handout, but unless the Farm Bill is amended, he says farmers won't be able to survive severe natural disasters, like the back-to-back harvest storms. "When I'm dead, it's over," Rabon said. "My kids can't make a living farming, and I don't blame them. They watched me go broke and wore out." And when that happens, he asked, "Who will feed this country?" ___ Information from: The Sun News, http://www.thesunnews.com/ © 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Back to Reading News Metro Page Six Sports Business Opinion Entertainment Fashion Living Media Tech Real Estate Sub Menu 1 Photos Video Covers Columnists Horoscopes Sub Menu 2 Classifieds Subscribe Sign in In The News: hillary clinton iran lamar odom 2016 presidential election new york mets Sections Search Tips Sign in New York Post Most Popular 46,903 Trump's scandal-free son-in-law crosses aisle into his presidency Share this: Facebook Twitter Google WhatsApp Email Copy Business Share this: Facebook Twitter Google WhatsApp Email Copy How retailers plan to get shoppers in stores this Black Friday By Catherine Curan View author archive Get author RSS feed Name(required) Email(required) Comment(required) November 19, 2016 | 6:41pm Modal Trigger Photo: AP More On: black friday Woodbury Common is hooking up shoppers with Black Friday helicopter rides More retailers plan to be closed on Thanksgiving Christmas sales figures are the best in at least five years Online shopping is useful even at the store Target has a secret for Black Friday: Buy a holiday gift from the chain online, and you’ll get it from a brick-and-mortar store. As the make-or-break holiday selling season kicks off Friday, 1,060 Target stores will ship online orders directly to customers. That’s up more than sevenfold from 2014. Invisible to shoppers, this move slashes delivery times and costs, while helping turn hundreds of stores nationwide from a potential liability into a competitive tool for additional sales. “Leveraging our stores as flexible fulfillment centers … to deliver the last mile, we think that’s a huge competitive advantage,” said Target Chief Executive Brian Cornell in the company’s third-quarter earnings conference call. Brick-and-mortar retailers will need every advantage they can find, despite a rosy forecast from Deloitte calling for holiday revenues to rise as much as 4 percent, to more than $1 trillion. However, the Deloitte report expects online holiday shopping sales to jump up roughly 19 percent, to $98 billion. To compete with Amazon, stores are trying to create a seamless shopping experience online or in-store, while offering steep discounts and exclusive merchandise — plus hearty helpings of the holiday hoopla that pulls shoppers in the doors. “Our hope is that … improving service in our stores, as well as improvements in our apps, will help … traffic,” Chief Financial Officer Karen Hoguet said during Macy’s third-quarter earnings call. While serving up a dizzying selection of discounts, retailers are stretching the definition of Black Friday. Macy’s began its Black Friday preview sale on Nov. 17, and will offer those deals in stores on Thanksgiving at 5 p.m. Walmart started listing Black Friday discounts on its app 10 days ago, and most deals will be available on its Web site at 12:01 Thanksgiving morning. Price cuts alone aren’t enough. Target has increased its new and exclusive assortment of toys 15 percent, to roughly 1,800 items. Walmart has more than 400 toy exclusives, including a $398 Disney Princess carriage, and has stocked more than 1.5 million TVs. Best Buy and Target are offering free shipping for the entire holiday season, and Amazon has upped its game: Customers who’ve paid an annual membership fee can receive more than 100 Black Friday sale items in an hour or less in Brooklyn, Manhattan and 29 other metro areas, a 50 percent increase from last year. But, for now at least, there’s one important holiday shopping highlight you can’t get online. On Black Friday, Macy’s Herald Square opens its 13,000-square-foot Santaland, one of seven nationwide that attract millions of customers every year. About Us   Log in or Register!   Top News U.S. News World News Entertainment Movies Music TV Odd News The Almanac Business Security Industry Energy Industry Sports Fantasy Football NFL NBA MLB NHL Golf Tennis College Football College Basketball Science Health Opinion Photos Latest Photos 2016 Olympics News Entertainment Sports Features Archives Archive Home / Top News / U.S. News Hate incidents since election tapering off, now top 700 in online survey By Eric DuVall   |   Updated Nov. 19, 2016 at 3:51 PM Follow @upi Comments | License Photo WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Incidents of racial hate and other forms of discrimination since the election now top 700 in an anecdotal survey being conducted by he Southern Poverty Law Center, though the frequency of reports has declined significantly since the immediate aftermath of Donald Trump's election. In total, the SPLC reports 701 incidents were reported through the "Report Hate" page on its website since the Nov. 8 election. Sixty-five percent of the incidents -- some of which were verified by law enforcement or media reports and some of which remain anecdotal accounts -- took place in the three days following the election. By the middle of this week, the group said only a handful of incidents were being reported per day. The law center said the most frequent form of hateful incidents were anti-immigrant, with 206 such reports. Second was anti-black, with 151 reports. There were 80 anti-LGBT incidents reported. Other forms included incidents directed at Muslims, women and swastika-related graffiti. The Southern Poverty Law Center said 40 percent of all reports it received took place in an educational setting, either in kindergarten through 12th grade, or on college campuses. However, the group said hate incidents have cropped up in virtually every setting. "They've been everywhere -- in schools, in places of business like Walmart, on the street," SPLC President Richard Cohen told CNN. Trump was asked about the rash of race-related incidents and addressed those responsible directly. "If it helps, I will say this, and I will say right to the cameras: Stop it," Trump said. Though much smaller in numbers, the Southern Poverty Law Center said it had received 27 reports of hate speech directed at Trump supporters in the days since the election, as well. With a history of reliable reporting dating back to 1907, today's UPI is a credible source for the most important stories of the day, continually updated  - a one-stop site for U.S. and world news, as well as entertainment, trends, science, health and stunning photography. UPI also provides insightful reports on key topics of geopolitical importance, including energy and security. A Spanish version of the site reaches millions of readers in Latin America and beyond. UPI was founded in 1907 by E.W. Scripps as the United Press (UP). It became known as UPI after a merger with the International News Service in 1958, which was founded in 1909 by William Randolph Hearst. Today, UPI is owned by News World Communications. Plus, our most popular articles and videos for the week ended Nov. 18. PrintCommentRecommend (-) By Morningstar.com | 11-19-16 | 05:00 AM | Email Article Inspired by Harper's Index (with a tip of the hat to FiveThirtyEight's Significant Digits blog), Morningstar Runs the Numbers uses a numbers-based approach to highlight recent Morningstar research, along with some outside news stories. About the Author Morningstar.com offers coverage of 950 stocks, 1,150 mutual funds, and 300 ETFs, plus market news, economic analysis, portfolio-planning insights, and investment commentary. Contact Author | Meet other investing specialists 2% Inflation expectations have been rising (to over 2% by some measures) since the election due to the expected combination of infrastructure spending and tax cuts. Karen Wallace wrote this week on what the market expects inflation to look like. Another market-based gauge of inflation is the 5-year, 5-year forward inflation expectation rate, which also shows an increase in expected inflation. It jumped from 1.89% on Nov. 8 to 1.97% on Nov. 9, and was over 2% as of Nov. 10. As the name implies, clumsily, this is an expectation of inflation over the five-year period that begins five years from today. Some prefer this measure to the [TIPS] breakeven inflation rate, because longer-term inflation expectations tend not to be as affected by cyclical factors. $1 trillion The market seems to think Donald Trump's campaign pledge to spend $1 trillion over 10-years on infrastructure has a good chance of happening. But Kristoffer Inton thinks the package isn't a done deal and that given the run-up in share prices of building materials firms there isn't much investment opportunity today. We’re skeptical that the touted $1 trillion infrastructure spending plan will be executed in its proposed form. We think the shares of these companies are now pricing in significant growth, and we see little risk-adjusted upside at this time. 13% Only 13% of actively managed equity funds beat a comparable Vanguard index fund on an after-tax basis for the 10-years ending June 2016 per a new Morningstar study. Jeff Ptak concludes that this means trying to buy active stock funds in a taxable account is a bad idea. Most U.S. active equity funds failed to beat a relevant Vanguard index fund before and after taxes. This is not an isolated occurrence, as the clear majority of these funds have failed to beat a comparable index fund over most of the 10-year periods we studied. Given these long odds, investors should think twice about putting taxable money to work in active stock funds. 9  Wal-Mart reported its ninth consecutive quarter of positive U.S. same store sales growth this week. Erin Lash thinks the continued investments in the business (which are weighing on profits) remain prudent and that shares are starting to look attractive. We don’t expect to materially alter our $76 per share fair value estimate for wide-moat Wal-Mart after third-quarter results that included a more than 2% bump in local currency sales but a nearly 60-basis-point erosion in operating margin to 4.3%. Despite the near-term hit to profits, we’ve long thought that the firm’s decision to ramp up investments behind people and technology is essential for the long-term health of the business, and we view this spending as prudent to support its leading competitive edge. Negative 0.2%  Target , on the other hand, saw its same-store sales decline 0.2% in the quarter. This is an improvement though form the 1.1% decline seen in the second quarter. However, the bigger story was the jump in operating margins after the sale of the pharmacy business and other efforts to cut costs. Erin Lash thinks the profit gain is "notable" but she doesn't see the stock as attractively priced today. 17%  Home Depot's earnings per share jumped 17% in the third quarter, bucking the trend seen in weak results from some of the firm's key vendors like Sherwin-Williams and Whirlpool. Jaime Katz urges investors to be cautious in projecting these strong results indefinitely into the future.  Admittedly, these metrics are stellar considering we are well into a multi-year housing recovery that we expect will continue through the end of the decade but at a much slower pace than in the recent past. We think the election throws another layer of complexity into forecasting for the business, as Donald Trump's policies are likely to help U.S. domiciled businesses but hinder interest rates, potentially leading to slower housing turnover and slower growth (or possible declines) in housing prices, potentially changing the demand for home improvement longer term. We are considering these factors as offsets today and plan to maintain our $125 fair value estimate, rendering shares as fairly valued, trading at 18 times our 2017 estimate. Our main concern is that top-line growth will slow as improvement in the housing market slows, causing bottom-line growth to taper, as well. Area store hours for Thanksgiving, Black Friday Mickey Shuey , mshuey@gannett.com 6:06 p.m. EST November 19, 2016 Buy Photo Shoppers wait to gain entry into Victoria's Secret early on Black Friday. (Photo: Mike Emery/Palladium-Item)Buy Photo 44 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE At least 45 stores in the Richmond area will participate in Black Friday this year, a majority of them major retailers. About two dozen will begin "the biggest sale day of the year" a day early again this year, on Thanksgiving Day. Here is a listing of when each of the stores contacted by The Palladium-Item said they would be open to shoppers. Meijer Open 24 hours Sale starts at 6 a.m.; through Friday at midnight Kmart Opens 6 a.m.; through Friday at midnight Dollar General Open 7 a.m.-10 p.m.; reopens Friday at 8 a.m. Big Lots Open 7 a.m.-midnight.; reopens Friday at 6 a.m. CVS Open 8 a.m.-10 p.m.; reopens Friday at 8 a.m. Walgreens Open 8 a.m.-10 p.m.; reopens Friday at 8 a.m. JCPenney Opens at 3 p.m.; runs through Friday at 11 p.m. Best Buy Open 5 p.m.-1 a.m.; reopens Friday at 8 a.m. Elder Beerman Opens at 5 p.m.; through Friday at 10 p.m. Dunham's Sports Opens at 5 p.m.; through Friday at 10 p.m. Hibbett Sports Richmond Square Mall Open 6-11 p.m.; reopens 7 a.m. Friday Claire's Boutique Richmond Square Mall Open 6-11:30 p.m.; reopens 6 a.m. Friday Justice Richmond Square Mall Open 6 p.m.-midnight; reopens 6 a.m. Friday Finish Line Richmond Square Mall Open 6 p.m.-midnight; reopens 8 a.m. Friday Shoebilee Richmond Square Mall Open 6 p.m.-midnight; reopens 8 a.m. Friday Dick's Sporting Goods Open 6 p.m.-2 a.m.; reopens Friday at 5 a.m. Journeys Richmond Square Mall Open 6 p.m.-2 a.m.; reopens Friday at 5 a.m. Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 p.m.; through Friday at 10 p.m. Individual store hours, listed, vary American Eagle Outfitters Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 p.m.; through Friday at 10 p.m. Victoria's Secret Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 p.m.; through Friday at 10 p.m. Kohl's Opens at 6 p.m.; through Friday at midnight Walmart Open 24 hours Starts at 6 p.m.; through Friday at midnight Stores opening Friday These stores will have one-day sales on Black Friday and are listed in the order in which they will open. Game Stop Opens at 5 a.m. Trinity Christian Store Opens at 5 a.m. Lowes Home Improvement Opens at 6 a.m. Jo-Ann Fabrics Opens at 6 a.m. Bath & Body Works Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 a.m. Christopher & Banks Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 a.m. GNC Live Well Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 a.m. Maurices Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 a.m. Rogers Jeweler Richmond Square Mall Opens at 6 a.m. Menard's Opens at 6 a.m. T.J. Maxx Opens at 7 a.m. Dillard's Opens at 8 a.m. Hobby Lobby Opens at 8 a.m. Nirvana Richmond Square Mall Opens at 8 a.m. Luxe Lizzies Opens at 9 a.m. Warm Glow Candle Opens at 9 a.m. Bullerdick Furniture Opens at 9:30 a.m. Esmond's Shoes Opens at 9:30 a.m. Richmond Furniture Gallery Opens at 9:30 a.m. Veach's Toy Station Opens at 10 a.m. Embellish Opens at 10 a.m. 765 Clothing Opens at 10 a.m. Dance With Me Bridal & Formal Wear Opens at 11 a.m. Ply Fiber Arts Opens at 11 a.m. Palladium-Item business reporter Mickey Shuey will provide live coverage of #BlackFriday47374 starting 3 p.m. Thursday. Some restaurants to stay open on Thanksgiving Mickey Shuey , mshuey@gannett.com 1 p.m. EST November 19, 2016 Mouth-watering golden roasted turkey over white background, no garnish.. (Photo: evgenyb, Getty Images/iStockphoto) Although most area restaurants will be closed on Thanksgiving, there are some places that plan to stay open to give early shoppers, and those who would prefer not to cook, a way to still get food on the national holiday. The Palladium-Item compiled a list of at least 19 restaurants in Wayne County that will maintain hours on Thanksgiving, ranging from fast food and delivery, to casual and fancy, sit-down dining. Thanksgiving The following restaurants are scheduled to be open on Thanksgiving. Applebee's 4425 National Road E., Richmond Open 11 a.m.-11 p.m. Bertie's Music Bar 1129 E. Main St., Richmond 9 a.m.-3 a.m. 21-and-up only Bob Evans All area locations 6:30 a.m.-8 p.m. Burger King 4630 National Road E., Richmond Opens at 11 a.m. All other Burger Kings closed Cracker Barrel 6050 National Road E., Richmond 6 a.m.-10 p.m. Domino's All area locations 10:30 a.m.-2 a.m. Fricker's 3237 Chester Blvd., Richmond 5 p.m.-1 a.m. Golden Corral 3625 National Road E., Richmond 10:30 a.m.-9 p.m. Hardee's 1925 Chester Blvd., Richmond 5 a.m.-noon Breakfast only IHOP 540 W. Eaton Pike, Richmond Open 24 hours Lakeview Restaurant 1219 National Road, Cambridge City 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Reservations only, call (765) 478-3661 Little Caesar's All area locations 11 a.m.-10:30 p.m. Old Richmond Inn 138 S. Fifth St., Richmond Opens at 11 a.m. Reservations only, call (765) 962-2247 Papa John's 1520 E. Main St., Richmond 10:15 a.m.-1 a.m. Steak 'n Shake 5901 National Road E., Richmond 7 a.m.-midnight Subway Walmart location only, Richmond 5 p.m.-11 p.m. All other Subways closed Sunshine Cafe 1400 National Road W., Richmond Open 24 hours White Castle 5801 National Road E., Richmond Noon-8 p.m. Willie and Red's 40 E. Main St., Hagerstown 11 a.m.-5 p.m. Reservations only, call (765) 489-4131 Black Friday The following locations will have special operating hours, or will be closed, Black Friday: AJ's Diner 1600 E. Main St., Richmond Closed Lee's Famous Recipe All area locations Closed Square Donuts (east) 3600 block of National Road East, Richmond Opens at 3 a.m. Square Donuts (west) 1241 N.W. Fifth St., Richmond Drive-thru opens at 10 p.m. Thursday Warehouse Cafe 213 N. Third St., Richmond Closed If you know of a restaurant in Wayne County that's not on this list, email mshuey@gannett.com with the restaurant and its hours. We'll update this story online with any suggested restaurants we receive. Palladium-Item business reporter Mickey Shuey will provide live coverage of #BlackFriday47374 starting 3 p.m. Thursday. [Poll] BuzzWorthy 2016-11-19 WWII Shipwrecks Vanish From Pacific Ocean: Sunken Dutch, British Warships, And A U.S. Submarine Mysteriously Disappear From Bottom Of Java Sea SUBSCRIBE Full RSS Feed Latest News Feed Entertainment News Feed Tech Feed World News Gaming Feed Sports Feed Funny & Strange Feed Health Feed Lifestyle Feed BuzzWorthy Feed Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Delivered To Your INBOX Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Email Address Or follow us online Facebook Twitter Google-plus Rss Black Friday Will Not Be The Biggest Shopping Day Of 2016, Experts Say Shopping 3 0 0 November 19, 2016 Black Friday Will Not Be The Biggest Shopping Day Of 2016, Experts Say Chris Featherstone Every year, the day after Thanksgiving presents a time of chaos in the world of shopping. From the latest toys, furniture, and appliances, to the latest gadgets, an overwhelming amount of people visit retail stores throughout the entire day. According to The Balance, 74.2 million people shopped on Black Friday in 2015. However, the numbers are declining, as 87 million shopped in 2014, 92 million shopped in 2013, and 85 million shopped in 2011. Because of these numbers, another day seems to potentially eclipse this shopping-day juggernaut. According to Business Insider, the new day for top sales will belong to December 23, two days before Christmas. In addition, Shelley Kohan of RetailNext asserts that “the significance of Black Friday has waned in recent years as retailers have started launching their post-Thanksgiving sales earlier, with many now starting them on Thanksgiving Day.” Kohan has a point. Especially, since many retailers have decided to open their stores on the evening of Thanksgiving to avoid long lines at four or five o’clock in the morning. Small Business Trends also affirms the December 23 date, based on another comment from Kohan. “This year, with Christmas falling on a Sunday, most shoppers will want to cut short their shopping early on Saturday, December 24, leaving the day before, Friday, as retail’s biggest opportunity for sales. For store visits, Super Saturday will lead the way, with Black Friday a very close second.” The history of the term “Black Friday” spans nearly 150 years. Originally, the term was not used for a shopping spree, but a result of the crash in the United States gold market, according to History. However, despite the inaccurate accounts of retailers earning a profit only during the Thanksgiving season, as well as slave owners buying slaves at a discounted rate, History reveals the truth behind the modern-day use of the term. “The true story behind Black Friday, however, is not as sunny as retailers might have you believe. Back in the 1950s, police in the city of Philadelphia used the term to describe the chaos that ensued on the day after Thanksgiving, when hordes of suburban shoppers and tourists flooded into the city in advance of the big Army-Navy football game held on that Saturday every year. Not only would Philly cops not be able to take the day off, but they would have to work extra-long shifts dealing with the additional crowds and traffic. Shoplifters would also take advantage of the bedlam in stores to make off with merchandise, adding to the law enforcement headache.” To add to this, there have been a slew of crime-related incidents that occurred on Black Friday. In 2008, 34-year-old Jdimytai Damour, a temporary seasonal employee at Walmart, was fatally killed during her 5 am shift after about 200 people stampeded the store in hopes to capture the best deals. <noscript><iframe width="500" height="375" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/DZWqyU_eUDA?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></noscript> In 2013, 61-year-old Ronnie Sharp and 35-year-old Christopher Jackson were arguing over a parking lot space at a Walmart in Claypool Hill, VA. Sharp pulled out a gun, as well as stabbed Jackson in the arm, cutting him down to the bone. Both men were jailed for the incident. <noscript><iframe width="500" height="281" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Yzm39Dr7HfY?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></noscript> Situations such as these elicit great concern for retail stores, and causes many to mandate better policies for shoppers. For instance, Walmart recently sent out a press release, promising a better sales experience for this year’s Black Friday. Their solution is to open earlier, which would hopefully give customers a wider range to find good deals. Even with this, the stigma of Black Friday shopping will not go away, and this is shown by the declining numbers. Along with the growing popularity of Cyber Monday, according to Forbes, along with the popularity of December 23 last-minute shopping, the Black Friday phenomenon seems to be fading away. Toggle navigation Toggle navigation Home Samachar News Finance SPORTS Movies Bawarchi Astrology Videos Gold rates DUBAI GOLD RATES RUPEE Jobs Health Antzill Techtalk Web Sify Search Sify.com News International U.S.: Indian-American woman faces hate attack after bandana mistaken as 'hijab' U.S.: Indian-American woman faces hate attack after bandana mistaken as 'hijab' Source : Last Updated: Sat, Nov 19, 2016 21:52 hrs Post your Comments Tweet Mail Print [U.S.], Nov. 19 (ANI): The fears that were growing before Donald Trump shocked the world by winning the race to the White House, have begun manifesting and a prime example of the murky situation is the attack on Nicki Pancholy from California, whose ethnicity is Rajastani Indian, but a mere bandana on her head was mistaken as a 'hijab' and provoked an attack. NBC Bay area reported that Pancholy was saddened and scared when she came down from her "peace walk" on Monday afternoon to find a note on the hood of her car which read, "Hijab wearing b**** this is our nation now get the f*** out." "When I saw it, I was in shock. That someone would feel so much hate to do this. I realize that this is the climate after this election. But I didn't realize someone would be so ignorant and in so much pain to cause so much harm," she said, adding that she was wearing a bandana over her head, not because she is religious, but because she is protecting her scalp from the sun because has lupus, an inflammatory autoimmune disease that can damage tissues and organs. However, she has forgiveness the miscreant for writing her that hate filled note "I forgive you. Please stop your self-hatred. In harming me, you are harming yourself," she said out loud to the author of the note. Meanwhile, in less than two weeks since the transition into Trump's presidency began, over 700 "hateful harassment" attacks have been reported across the United States. According to a report by the Southern Poverty Law Center, 701 such attacks have been reported in which immigrants, blacks, LGBT-people, Muslims and women were targeted. "They've been everywhere - in schools, in places of business like Walmart, on the street," SPLC President Richard Cohen said. The civil rights advocacy group compiled its report by collecting direct submissions from its #ReportHate intake page, as well as through monitoring news articles and social media sites. Anti-immigrant sentiment was at the top of the list with 206 reported attacks, while anti-woman and anti-Trump attacks remained at the bottom with 36 and 27 reported attacks respectively. A total of 151 incidents targeted black people, 80 targeted LGBT-people, 51 targeted Muslims and 60 involved swastikas. However, in a 60 Minutes interview on Sunday, Trump said he wasn't aware of all these hateful acts, but when he was told that they indeed exist, Trump turned to the camera and simply said, "Stop it."
